title: "Money before customers"
pros: Nationwide allows employee to work remotely up to three days a week, which reduces the stress of commuting everyday. There is access to a two story gym in both the Des Moines and Columbus campuses.
cons: Over the last year, Nationwide has gone from a customer service driven company to a money is all that matters mindset. The room for advancement within the company has become very difficult within the last year. Bonuses were once a year, and very minimal for associates. Merit increases are less than the inflation rate, which has caused leaders to suggest to associates to leave the company and return so they can have the ability to re-negotiate their salary.

title: "Honest assessment"

Several people are out on medical leave due to stress. You don't get paid to work OT but must do so to try to keep up. Everyone has over 100 claims. Impossible to meet your goals even working OT. They can't find anyone to fill open positions that have been available since October.

title: "Be careful if you are military"
pros: People were nice, good benefits, good work atmosphere.
cons: I worked for Nationwide for about a year and a half total. I was deployed for about 10 months of that time frame. Upon coming home from my deployment, I had resigned since I found a new job. I was then sent a bill in the mail saying I owed about $3400 to Nationwide, due to hours that were not able to process in their system, that they "paid" me for. I went through a 2 month period of going back and forth with them, trying to explain that if I was over paid that amount of money, I would have realized it. I ended up settling the issue with them (right around the Christmas holidays), and owed them around $450 for money that was over paid to me. The entire issue was that when I was on drill weekends, even though I would request to not be paid from the company while I was not there, they still continued to pay me. I did not realize the entire time that I worked there. The company ran an audit back in March (while I was deployed) and found the issue, but did not mention it to me at all until I came home. So a great holiday season to me, when I have an unexpected bill of $500. I understand that if you overpaid me, that I have to pay it back. But the fact that they even over paid me in the first place, and then didn't mention it to me until 7 months later. If you are in the military and drill, be careful of how you input your time into their system, or you may receive a hefty bill from them down the road. Overall, the company/people/benefits were great, and I enjoyed my time working there, but I felt betrayed by the company for how they handled my situation.

pros: Pay above normal than other companies in the area but that’s about it.
cons: I have worked 8 years for this company and have gotten to see many stages of change which is normal in the corporate world. But when I started it seemed like one of those dream companies where they recognize hard work and everyone is engaged in the work they do. And they tell you this in the interview, on the walls where they post their values and just about every company email but the ones that stick around know the truth. The best advice I can give is get the experience you need, get your degree on them and leave for greener pastures before the smell of the poo rises to high. The only way to move up in the company is to be a brown nose or be related to a person that gives you a recommendation. Other wise your experience and work ethic get you no where.

title: "Great place to work in IT"
pros: Our IT department has been really great to work for. They are really good about encouraging continuous learning and provide time away from your job to do it. They also really help you develop and will help you get into other areas of development you are interested. If you wanted to go from being a cobol developer to a java developer they will help you make that transition. Pay is right around what other companies pay from what I have seen. The best thing about the company is work life balance and flexibility. Having kids requires you to work from home sometimes when they are sick and they allow you to do that and the hours are flexible too as long as your 8 hour day falls in the core hours of 9-3. So you can work 7-3 or 9-5 and you can shift that when ever you need to. So having a family that is the best benefit to me. Also we do Agile development so we commit to work we can complete in a 2 week period so there is not overtime or stress about working more than your 8 hours.
cons: Not much web or mobile development in Des Moines. Promotions can take while to get. Usually you need to post for a different job to get a promotion. They have promotions in place but it would take 4-5 years and lots of extra things outside of your job to get promoted.

title: "Find a profitable insurance company to work for!"
pros: Some work from home depending on the dept Good place to start if you have no insurance background
cons: Unfortunately, Nationwide is struggling with their loss ratios and making cuts left and right. When someone leaves, they no longer backfill the position...just split it up between the remaining team. They have rolled out LEAN (which is effectively a program that puts all problems back onto it the employees to fix). Everything is numbers driven, so you have to explain why you have had a less productive day. Micro-managing in its definition. No growth opportunities (obviously) and they struggle to retain talent. The last 3 positions I took were lateral, meaning no raise. Pay is far below industry average so top talent goes elsewhere. They try to make up for the lacking pay in “culture”...but you can’t feed your family with culture. I worked for NW for almost a decade and saw a very, very low moral and apathy from leadership in the past few years. No real direction...very reactive to the market instead of proactive. There is a reason they grew so fast...they wrote pretty much everything for years, and now dealing with the consequences of that in terms of loss ratios. If you are reading this and currently with NW, do yourself a favor and check out other companies. I easily found a position offering 30% more pay with about half of the workload. If you are looking to work at Nationwide, the only advantage would be when you’re new to insurance and need an education. They do that well.

title: "Not trending in the right direction"
pros: Great co-workers, great facility. Medium level management was great, but above that was absolutely terrible with their decision making.
cons: Loved working here for the first few years, but things are definitely not trending in the right direction. There is essentially a hiring freeze which is going to last throughout the year (this happened last year too), so advancement is almost non-existent. People constantly have to take lateral jumps so they don't go crazy. They don't seem to care about retaining top talent, which is why a lot of people are jumping ship. Mediocre pay, below-average benefits, below-average bonus. Very low yearly raises (even for top performers). If you're looking for a role in Claims - you may want to steer clear. They implemented LEAN recently and it has basically just been about numbers and not the employee ever since. People now get put onto written warnings for things outside of their control.

cons: Company has been going through many transitions and has caused a lot of micro managing. Career Advancement is a joke for the entry level positions due to cutbacks Systems are horrible computers are always crashing Nationwide is still behind and is trying to play catch up with there IT division

title: "Great diversity commitment, you just never knowif your job is going to be there next month."

cons: It often feels like change is made only for the sake of change. Work life balance is spoken of but does not appear to be realized. Management turnover is high. 6 direct managers in 4 years.

title: "So-so"
pros: Good pay, locations across US, cafeteria at my location
cons: Long hours, management doesn't seem to care, not enough opportunity to grow, not enough employees which equals high work load

title: "Impossible to grow within company, NO work/life balance"
pros: Paid Time Off accural, the 401K with company match, brand new office in Grandview with covered parking, discounted COSI and Columbus Zoo tickets
cons: The work-life balance is nonexistent. All management and the company care about is working you until you can't anymore. I am not important at work. Raises and promotions are next to none. If you leave, they will eventually bring in a contract employee through Randstad or Taylored Management to replace you. It is a revolving door. When you ask for help, you are told no, every single time. Extremely understaffed and underpaid. You will not receive help. You are told that you are struggling because you aren't good enough, and need to be coached and mentored, although the problems are clear throughout the IPSO department. The daily pressure is enormous. Lunches and breaks are not possible. Taking time off is difficult, and you will be contacted on your cell phone when you are out of the office, about your work & what needs done; NO work life balance. They are always promoting engagement and being active in committees and groups, but there is no time. You can't take the time out of your already not long enough 7.75hr day to be involved in anything. All they care about is how much you can produce.

title: "Stressful disorganize"

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Nationwide focuses and diversity in the workforce and invests in developing its associates. The benefits and salary offered by Nationwide show the company is dedicated to the growth of its employees as the insurance industry rapidly changes. The company offers tuition reimbursement, along with paid time off for both parents for births and adoptions, to name a few of the great things there is to offer. In addition to the employee benefits, the company is investing in its strategy and technology to ensure that our customers needs from insurance to financial are covered from youth through retirement years and beyond.
cons: Nationwide has made many changes recently in its strategy and organizational structure. Although these may have seemed like cons during times of transition, they are actually a benefit to the employees and customers. With over 10 years in the company, I have little negative to say. If opportunities arise, senior leaders are quick to devote time in identifying solutions and taking action.

title: "Awesome place to work!"
pros: I love just about everything about being a Media Design Consultant at Nationwide! Being on the Corporate Communications team, I'm able to use lots of my creative abilities with a wide variety of clients. My co-workers are fabulous, my boss is too, as is his boss and her boss! I've only been here a few months and so far, I have no complaints. I feel valued for my skills and expertise. I'd always heard that Nationwide really knows how to take care of its employees, and I'm experiencing that first-hand every day at work. The best professional experience of my career. Love it!
cons: If I had to find something for this category, I suppose the parking situation is not the most ideal. But I imagine that's a result of working downtown in general, not specific to Nationwide.

They posted for one position and after taking the position on a lot lower than market pay, became a position of what ever they needed at the moment. Only worked on a project after another person had left the group because of the same thing. To much old school management where everyone ran to the manager for permission for everything. Can't make their own decisions. Stuck in their own process for documentation. And their story/test cases are atrocious. Expect you to read their minds and then judged you when you made a mistake and then shunned you.

pros: Nationwide is among the best of the best at listening to its employees. This is done with yearly surveying, quarterly random selections cross department meetings, and the personal weekly touch of on the ground supervisors. If you want to live and breath the corporate world, and you want it to care, this is the place for you. They also provide assistance for further education. The hidden gem is the Nationwide Library. Any tittle of self help book, audio book, or video is accessible no matter your location.
cons: If you are not at headquarters in Ohio, advancement can stall out. Solution is to be open to relocating.

title: "Decent company, not much room to advance"

title: "Doesn’t value their employees"
pros: Coworkers have always been the best thing about the company. Some locations have free parking and a free gym.
cons: Where to start? Multiple reorganizations over the more than decade I’ve been there. Lack of transparency from leadership, although they promise it, it’s not delivered. You can expect to be silo’d with zero cross department training. And also expect to pigeonholed. Some leaders are great, others are not. Some leaders actually manadate no performance ratings over a certain level for the entire department. No consistency between departments. As for their ‘Greatest Places to Work’ award - not every employee participates or even receives the poll. Top leadership is in such a hurry to have a ‘plan’ they don’t bother the think through the intended and unintended consequences, so a few months down the road, they’ll change their minds and off they’ll go in another direction . Constance upheavals in process. Because the company is so severely silo’d - multiple versions of the same operations/systems- wasted money that they attempt to remedy through layoffs of experienced personnel. Don’t expect that your high performance will save you from a lay-off - if your job code is selected, you’ll just be gone, performance doesn’t matter. Nor will decades with the company. And while they will give lip service to trying to place you in a new position- that’s all it is. They need to change their slogan because they can hardly offer “On your side” service by slashing as much experience as they have over the last few years. Benefits: bare minimum. In spite of being self insured for many of the products, including health insurance- high prices and high deductibles. And a paternalistic attitude including health screenings that while not mandatory, if you don’t participate, you’ll be paying even more for your health insurance. Because of the understaffing, work hours are often long and carry over to the weekends. Expect to figure out your own solutions as training is spotty and leadership very well may not have the experience to guide you.

title: "Anywhere but Harleysville location"
pros: Great 401k and other benefits but health is high deductible
cons: Seems like they may be moving to close Harleysville

title: "Unprofessional Small Unit Leadership"
pros: Great on training Very friendly employees
cons: Unprofessional mid management. I was bullied and rude comments made about me as a veteran with PTSD and also comments made about my husband being older than me. I reported it to HR but feel that nothing was really resolved. I received cold sholders from other managers after I reported the issue. I left the company and now my anxiety from work has gone away. This company prides itself on diversity but I totally felt the disrespect when it came to my relationship.

title: "Depressing"
pros: A large company with a good historical record.
cons: They have completely changed from a good company to a truly awful one. Seems like they are trying to ruin company on purpose. They are very dishonest about their plans. They have terribly outdated technology, which they pretend they have been investing in for years. 90% of their job postings are fake to skew headlines. They just post a job perform a couple of cursory interviews and then take it down unfilled. They aren't changing technology, they are outsourcing to low wage contractors.

title: "Review"

cons: Multiple reorganizations lead to associate layoffs.

title: "Constant Layoffs"

cons: Awful medical benefits. Company is top heavy. Too many management levels. Constant layoffs hurt employee morale and create the uncertainty. How are employees supposed to provide excellent customer service to members when they are in constant fear of losing their jobs?

title: "Good"
pros: Flexibility with times in and off
cons: Not a lot of growth

title: "Great Insurance Company but not a software shop"
pros: as Nationwide pet, it had a very stable financial background. Great location with great friendly people to work with. forward thinking, in business aspects and in technology. a lot of independence and one's voice could be heard.
cons: an insurance company growing into a software shop had a lot of growing pains. low pay for national or local average. no synergy. Bonuses and recognition went to sales team for selling the software the development team made. Sales would oversell and over promise and Dev team had to pick up the deadline promised by another team.

title: "Great Culture and Work Life Balance"
pros: Great work life balance. Haven't had any bad experiences with leadership.
cons: I don't have any cons.

title: "Curent layoffs"
pros: I had two stints at Nationwide. Overall a good company with good managers and employee buy in for what they're doing. Good culture of giving back. I worked in the Santa Rosa office years ago when it was Allied Insurance. Nationwide bought Allied and a couple of years closed that office and moved to Sacramento. Bummer, but everyone really had almost a year to find alternative employment. And I did. Always grateful that they gave everyone that lead time. Fast forward ten years. I find myself in Sacramento and re-hired by Nationwide. Good experience. Actually, better in Sacramento. Good caring people. Stayed for about three years when I found a better opportunity. At that time underwriters were no longer assigned to individual agents - hence no real relationship building. Once that happened, it seemed there was no reason someone sitting in the home office couldn't do what I was doing. Personal lines was mostly automated. Now commercial lines is heading that way and I hear employees are being laid off.
cons: Can't blame a company for doing what they need to do, but they reorganize too often for employees who don't want to relocate when offices do close. Having said that, they do try to treat employees well.

title: "Manager"
pros: Large company, comprehensive benefits package, historically strong culture of community involvement and caring for employees.
cons: Going through a massive restructuring and trying to find it's new identity. Limited opportunities in the near future for personal promotion and growth.

title: "Benefits are good"
pros: Benefits, work life balance, location, culture
cons: Massive lay offs every year

title: "Lots of Change"
pros: Flexible. PTO is decent but is mixed with sick pay.
cons: Alot of change going on right now with layoffs. Extra duties for the smae pay.

title: "Claims Adjuster"
pros: Decent pay for entry level. Great training for someone new to insurance. Good benefits. Positive work environment. Personal Development opportunities.
cons: No flexibility in claims. Limited PTO.

title: "Inconsistent Company, layoffs, top heavy organization"
pros: Room for advancement. I had several terrific managers throughout my career.
cons: There has been intense change for several years and it doesn’t end up working out or improve profitability. It results in constant staffing changes, layoffs, and lack of underwriting consistency. Recent announcements are resulting in several layoffs in commercial and PL underwriting, claims, risk control and product. In a booming economy this is a troubling concern while other carriers are looking for talent, NW is laying them off. The organization is too top heavy with too many people with random VP titles. There is a lack of consistency in commercial underwriting for target markets. IMO Nationwide tries to be everything to everybody in commercial resulting in a terrible combined ratio.

title: "Fine company, sub-par benefits"
pros: Company engagement Many different niches for all interests Job security (unless in sales/marketing) 401k
cons: Terrible health insurance Certain departments don't live up to the company's insistence on work-life balance

title: "High Expectations Without Reward"
pros: Typical Monday- Friday hours, No Holidays or Weekends. Heavy workload keeps you busy.
cons: Micromanagement at it's best! Little training or support. Very negative environment.

title: "Emoloyee Review"
pros: Good PTO. Generally good people to work with and flexible
cons: A lot of silos that can make it hard to know who all has be involved with different things

title: "Do not work at Nationwide"
pros: Work from home opportunities Lots of resource groups depending on interests Maternity leave 4 weeks Very receptive to helping those with disabilities and medical work condition requirements.
cons: Depending on the department you’re in you may not be able to utilize all resource groups the company has. Constant system issues Focus not not the quality, but quantity while demanding outrageous quality standards. Succeeding here sometimes feels like succeed in a vacuum, it’s almost impossible some days. Updates made monthly to become more “big brother” like environment. Despite boasting to “Work as one Nationwide” the departments have almost no interaction/communication with one another leading to so much confusion for internal employees and customers. Male leaders sexist towards women in terms of bonuses/raises, daily standards, and behaviors in general. Layoffs are the new norm and even if you’re not currently at risk of a layoff supervisors constantly bring up possibilities if you don’t perform above goals. Leaders make threats to withhold bonuses and raises and threaten to demote if you decline to take on advancement roles. Unable to request time off unless more than a month in advance. Outdated/very strict occurrence policy. 1/2 an occurrence for being more than 5 mins late, that’s insane. Attendance policy also encourages you to lie to supervisor. If your child/family is sick you get 1 occurrence per day you’re out. If your sick you get 1 occurrence for up to 5 days you’re out. My supervisor even told me to give him no details in the future or he’d be forced to give me multiple occurrences for telling the truth when I missed 2 days due to a sick child. Unable to seek assistance from leaders when needed as they’re always in meetings, even harder for WFH associates. I could go on and on, but I truly wish I’d avoided this company.

title: "Awesome company to work"
pros: you can balance your personal life with work
cons: less salary than the market

title: "Financial Services"
pros: Great coworkers, benefits and room for growth
cons: Pay is low given job market

title: "Great company to work for"
pros: Good salaries, good technology, easy going management
cons: Limited locations depending on position desired

title: "Working for NW Financial is fine/working for Nationwide Ins is not"
pros: Good people to work with. Some buildings are nice to work in. Include cafeterias, fitness centers, nice common areas. Most people can work remotely a few days a week if they want...although your manager will monitor your activity by watching your skype availability which clocks you if you don't hit your keyboard every 5 minutes. You can change the number of minutes but most people don't know it.
cons: The company is run by HR and Finance. Business unit leaders have no say in how their departments are run. This results in refusal to staff properly and adjuster workloads run 80% higher than target. Upper leadership responds by offering comments such as "change isn't for everybody." There are annual layoffs. The organization is constantly in flux which keeps everyone on edge. There is always a plan and the plan is always changing which makes it difficult to trust that anyone really has a vision for what the company wants to be. NW purchased Harleysville insurance several years ago which is a complete disaster. The systems won't integrate, most of the business has been run off, agency relationships suffer because Nationwide doesn't know how to compete with other insurers who write the same business. This leads to agents not wanting to write business with us so premium is shrinking and the insurance operation lost $400M last year. People are so detached from results that upon hearing the amount of lost revenue they are still wandering around asking how much their bonus will be. It may have been a good place to work at one time. People who have been here for 20+ years say it was. And now they're stuck here with nowhere to go and it is no longer a good place to work. Corporate values are not tied to leadership's behaviors in any way, shape or form. Attitudes toward front line workers are as ruthless as I have ever witnessed in any organization. Benefits are incredibly expensive. They cost $450/month for a family and come with a $6000 per person/$10,000 per family deductible. There is no opportunity for advancement since positions are simply eliminated if someone leaves. There are plenty of good infrastructure and people here is someone decides they actually want this to be an insurance company. Right now all the money is made by NW Financial and that is where all the focus is.

title: "Business Support"
pros: Company culture, great place to work
cons: I can not think of any

title: "Out of touch"
pros: Field level management is understanding and flexible, 18 days PTO (if you can use it) and paid holidays, CAT pay basically guaranteed multiple times a year
cons: Workload has grown to unrealistic levels and upper management focuses on justifying the workload rather than finding solutions. This is across the entire Nationwide claims platform Pay is mediocre for the industry standard and the raises are minimal regardless of performance levels now. "Profit sharing" is pathetic excuse of a bonus opportunity. When hired they will tell you that CAT is required and you may work 1-3 months depending how many major storms hit. 4 tours of CAT duty has been a light year for most adjusters I know over the last 3 years.

title: "Same As Any Other Job"
pros: Nationwide had a great atmosphere. Nice people, benefits; 401 K, PTO. There was a sense of comradery. The atmosphere was happier when I started. Once you meet your metrics there are opportunities to work from home twice a week. There was no outlook to extend it at the time but the building was pretty empty so, they may be going that route.
cons: After the layoffs, I think that it just got scary at Nationwide and the atmosphere just began to feel gloomy. Many employees were leaving or were laid off. The employees that stayed, felt overworked and under appreciated and the atmosphere became robotic. I believe that these feelings can happen anywhere because the company was obviously going through major changes. You can look around nationwide and get a feel for who will succeed. It's some part work ethic and part who you know. (Can happen anywhere) I got sick of feeling like I was in preschool. I believe that they were trying to establish some positive reinforcement but I really felt like my intelligence was being tampered with as we were coerced with prize boxes and ice cream days. I just didn't want to pretend that I didn't have work to do and as if I wasn't stressed with layoffs and people leaving, more work was piled on our desks (which happens anywhere.

title: "Call Center"
pros: Stable Company to work for
cons: Treated as an entry level call center employee including scheduling each minute of your day

title: "Nationwide has a problem and the ISR is the scapegoat"
pros: They say changes are coming, whatever that means
cons: Nationwide has a problem. Personal lines is overstaffed and rather than layoff employees properly every week introduces a new bullying tactic so they can accumulate statistical evidence to fire you because you could not meet these new improved goals and rules. Some of these include raising quality transformation goals which itself is already a mess, refusal to fix IT issues, a third world cell phone policy, and a brand new big brother esque software which tracks all your activity and provides reports to managers. The kicker being this is all preached as efforts to improve quality and efficiency.

title: "Good place to work"

title: "They don't care"
pros: Insurance, vacation time, honestly not much else
cons: The environment is toxic. Slowly in the 5 years I've worked there, they've moved away from "employees first" to "numbers and efficiency first". Today, there was a massive amount of snow and the roads are so bad the office should have closed. It's taking hours to get anywhere when it normally takes 15-30 minutes. We are at a level 1 snow emergency. The buildings are open. The opportunities to move or advance are solely based on who you know. They will block you even if you are fully qualified because they need you in the current department because it's understaffed. They laid off 1100 people and are now looking to hire people at a lower pay band. After giving a $1000 bonus after the tax changes last year. It's all about how much money the higher ups can make and how much corporate greed they can get away with. People walk on eggshells and don't actually speak their minds around higher ups because of backlash.

title: "Thought versus execution"
pros: Mostly good work culture (work life balance) People care about what they do Management encourages industry exposure Healthy comp package (401k match)
cons: Underlying work culture stained, talks well but executes poorly (agile,devops). "corporate welfare" meaning poor performers are hidden instead of dealt with Rewarded for incorrect behavior - "hitting the date but still missing the target"

title: "IT Project Manager"
pros: Not many that I recall.
cons: Favoritism, factory mentality. Lack of advancement opportunities, unless someone likes you. Dishonest and unqualified management. Management Resistant to change, too many long term employees.

title: "Good Company to work for"
pros: Laid Back and work culture is good
cons: Salary is below the market rate. Does not have a good bonus structure

title: "Good Place to work"
pros: IT department is relaxed and the people are very nice. Different areas have events, so you get a chance to interact with more people than on a typical day. Ability to flex your hours, with the requirement you are present for core work hours 9:30-3:30. This is nice so that you know people will at least be available during these times. Change seems to be coming, and upper level management is shifting decision power down towards those that do the work.
cons: Process bogs down productivity and ability to move faster. Changes are coming, but seem to not be discussed to everyone. Not everything is well documented, and as changes happen the documentation on systems tend to not be updated. The tools used for internal purposes could be replaced or at least updated.

title: "Ok Company"

title: "Great company but tough job"

cons: My particular role, Non-Injury Liability Adjuster, is busier and more stressful than it's worth. Consistently overworked, but maybe that's just corporate world...

title: "Great Company"
pros: Lots of room for innovation
cons: Limited promotional opportunities based on location outside Des Moines or Ohio

title: "Poor leadership driving this antiquated  company to the ground"
pros: Midwestern Company culture all around.
cons: General sexism, racism, and cronyism at the home office.

title: "Don't bank on retirement here."
pros: Work atmosphere is great. The people you work with are nice. Onsite gym and cafeteria.
cons: Turnover rate isn't great. Plus the layoffs year after year seem to be more of a reoccurring theme than a temporary restructuring. Layoffs are the norm and the fear of being next makes for a stressful environment. I wouldn't work here if your looking to retire with a company. It's a place to build your resume not stay.

title: "CSR"

title: "Good place to start"

title: "FORMER  SMALL MARKET ASSOCIATE UNDERWRITER"
pros: Great PTO benefits. Speaking from the prospective of my team, I never had to ask to take time off. Really the only stipulation was giving 24 hours notice. If something unexpected happened, mangers allowed you to go. Working for a large carrier looks great on your resume. I was able obtain several job offers very quickly. Lastly the people on my team were fun to work with
cons: The pay was well below industry average. The benefits are good, but not good enough to justify lower pay. Nationwide was expanding the role that I was in, and giving us more responsibilities, yet not increasing our pay. After 3.5 years, I was one of the more tenured team members in the small market underwriting department. I left the company chiefly because of pay: I had multiple job offers for similar work from other carriers each offering at least 10K more in salary. Lastly, there is a lot of favoritism among the managers. If you sat at the "cool kids table" , you would be promoted faster and got higher rises whether or not you are competent. I saw many incompetent people get promoted and assume roles they should not be in simply because of the people they know, while many of the competent people were either turned away or snubbed.

title: "Best company ever"

title: "Poor Corporate Leadership"
pros: If you are relocatable or located in Columbus/Des Moines, there is a lot of opportunity for advancement and lateral movement to a new department.
cons: This is a company with strong associates/direct managers, but is an unfortunate example of how poor corporate leadership leads to constant strategy changes. It’s an insurance heavyweight that has been far too slow to adapt to a changing market and truly lacks the vision to correct its trajectory. Financial plans are set based on what leadership and “the board” WANTS to happen as opposed to what WILL happen. Expenses are so far out of whack with the market, and their solution is to create a bunch of new departments with catchy names that make it seem like NW is far more relevant than it truly is. They can’t go 2 years without a complete shift in long term strategy. They are flailing.

title: "Choose Your Attitude"
pros: I have more than 30 years' business experience, and this is BY FAR the best company i have ever worked for. The compensation is fair and the benefits, like time off, 401K match and a Pension are awesome compared to other companies. There are lots of rules, some of which might strike you as arcane; but when you compare what's required to what's given, this place is Nirvhana!
cons: I despise the Nationwide-speak terms, like "Coaching" = discipline and "Opportunity" means a check mark against you, like arriving late. But if you let this cultural nonsense roll off your back, this is about the best career opportunity available in America, IMO.

title: "Property Claims adjuster"
pros: Great office, gym, food, nurse on site. Office space is really nice and co-workers are like family.
cons: Zero work life balance. All of the property claims department have been on 12 hour shifts for 10 months out of the year this year. Turnover rate is well over 50%. Management does not have a hold on what needs done and how to get it done. Adjusters are out on stress leave constantly and most of the time what we are told is later walked back and changed. Absolutely the worst managed place I have ever worked. If I could do it all over again I would have never accepted the job.

title: "It doesn't matter how hard you work"
pros: Coworkers are all relatively young (because turnover is so high) so it keeps a fun vibe around the office and there are opportunities to make friends. Within each team there is a lot of support and coworkers are all extremely helpful. I lucked out and got a great manager.
cons: Where to begin.... overwhelming work load that will absolutely crush your sprit if you're used to your hard work paying off. Completely different standards between managers and no one seems to know what the correct work flows or expectations are. No opportunity for advancement within the company. The AD literally told us to move to Columbus if we wanted to stay with Nationwide. It's typical corporate America where the people in charge are so disconnected they have no idea what we even do and believe they can continue to force more out of people who are already struggling to keep their head above water. Management tries to do nice things like surprise us with ice cream to keep morale up but associates on the floor are already so disillusioned and apathetic it doesn't make a difference.

title: "Do NOT work in claims."
pros: -You may develop Stockholm Syndrome if you work here. This is a facetions statement because I can't think of any positives. What I mean is that it is an emotionally abusive environment.
cons: I work in claims, so I have first-hand experience regarding what this company offers its customers and employees. -Culture stifles progress and innovation. -No work-life balance. -Archaic software. -Very limited advancement within the company. -HR department is used as a tool to keep leadership ahead and associates in their place. -Little regard for customers and employees below management level. -HR has no punitive structure, so you can be written up, fired, and have your career frozen without notice.

title: "Solid Company, Rigid IT, Great place to Retire"
pros: Good overall employee experience Great benefits Integrity filled workplace Sense of Job Security
cons: Frustrating for experienced individuals Processes and Protocols have replaced common sense Often difficult to accomplish basic job requirements due to processes Company has become overrun by inept contractors, and a lot of time is spent cleaning up after their messes or navigating sticky processes designed to cover up the inability of the workforce Lots of time is wasted waiting for requests to be filled by a small pool of infrastructure/middleware individuals who have the skeleton keys to all of the test and production servers and infrastructure - this is a maddening process where the individuals who know the most about the applications aren't able to access the servers to their test environments and instead have to walk other IT personnel through exactly what to do and wait days for it to be done, when a skilled developer could do it himself within minutes

title: "Good Company but No Future for Me"
pros: Nationwide is a decent company with a moral compass, which not all companies can say. They do a fairly good job of making associates feel treated like a human being. They also still provide a pension plan and nice company perks.
cons: Merit increases and incentive structures do not motivate individuals towards achievement. They are small enough to really be quite insignificant. The area I work in is not conducive to collaboration. My manager is great, but it is really hard to change such a large organization. Being someone who has not spent my whole career there, I am not valued like other associates of similar capabilities. Being in an office outside of the corporate headquarters, I am not really sure that I have the potential career growth opportunities that I desire long term... especially when that means potentially working in a different part of the organization.

title: "Great Company"
pros: Many ways to take time off, tons of vacation time.
cons: Communication within the department

title: "Nationwide Insurance Company Profile Review"
pros: In general, Nationwide has a great culture and a focus around valuing the diversity of talents and abilities each person brings to the table. Benefits and compensation are very competitive.
cons: My experience has been that the work/life balance becomes more difficult to manage as you move up into roles of increased responsibility. This is universally true regardless of employer and industry, and Nationwide is not an exception to this general rule.

title: "Claims adjuster"

cons: Extremely Poor work life balance

title: "mission critical electrician"
pros: profit sharing is a nice plus
cons: typical corporate management issues need addressed

title: "Do Yourself a Favor and Avoid"
pros: Pension and 18 days of Paid Time Off (if you get to use them)
cons: Company does not live up to its values that it preaches to its associates. They claim it’s a Great Company “for me, my family, and my future”; Great Opportunity “for my career and well being.” Then... they put you on Catastrophe duty (CAT duty). Which is whenever there is a catastrophe that affects a large number of policyholders your are expected to work 7:00am-7:00pm 7 days a week for 28 days. Which is fine if there is a major weather event that needs additional help. Now Nationwide has not been able to staff appropriately so they are putting associates on CAT duty to cover the lack of employees during normal business times. There are some people that have gone on 6,7, or even 8 CAT tours this year. This means that They have spent 6,7, or 8 months working 7:00am-7:00pm 7 days a week! I don’t even know how this is legal let alone meets Nationwide’s standards of “well-being” for employees or let’s the associate have any kind of work life balance. It’s also a viscous circle, you go on CAT because Nationwide is short staffed, people quit because they have to keep working CAT. Management is so out of tough with their employees it’s insane. Like the title states, do yourself a favor and avoid.

title: "Inside Property Claims Adjuster"
pros: Pay rate is why most people apply
cons: If you love your family DO NOT join the inside property unit. They do not care about you, your family or a work life balance. Most People in the department are on medication and have FMLA due to the extremely high stress level in the department. People are drowning in claims and management just wants more out of everyone

Here are my thoughts: The micromanagement is horrible, they write you adherence for everything and just want to find a way to correct you. HIGH ROTATION easily 20 people left my team in a span of 6 months. Team leads were rude and unprofessional whenever i ask them for help or any questions. The job was really degrading, it was just dealing complain about how bad is the banking system which leads me to an unfair system that does not protect you and only punish you.

title: "Nice place to work"

title: "Nationwide is a great place to work"

title: "Not as great as it used to be"
pros: - Good pay for the job - More freedom given as far as ways to solve customer issues - Fair employment practices - Recently a good employer as none of the things I list in cons now are things I would have listed a year ago
cons: - Convoluted metrics that are hard to understand - Tendency to revise metrics and retroactively change scores from previous months, making you fail things six months ago that were considered passing at the time. Changing future standards is find and understandable, but when I did well and then am suddenly told I no longer did well and are now on-notice instead of commended, that's an issue. - Not giving supervisors information about changes and forcing them to assume, resulting in getting different information from different supervisors and further confusing things - No clear quality standards so different QA reps score the same call in wildly different manners.

title: "Internal Sales Analyst"
pros: Good Work Life Balance, Management is good
cons: It is like a big highshcool and some management can be unprofessional

title: "Good place to work, but like anyworkplace it has its problems"

cons: For the ambitious, its slow and bureaucratic.

title: "Underwriter"

title: "Good collaborative company"

cons: Salary can be better, sick leaves need to be added.

title: "Tech Clerk"
pros: Good Company. All positive and decent.
cons: I didnt see many except better communication

title: "Senior tax analyst"
pros: Nice work area, conveniences like a cafeteria and workout facility onsite if downtown
cons: Parking is expensive and traffic is a nightmare. Most of the people there are awesome but there but a few make your life miserable.

title: "Insurance Agent"
pros: Interesting and busy job. Rarely a slow day.
cons: Work with a small group of people. Extremely lean on benefits. You need to keep a lot of information in your head to be good at it.

title: "Moving up in the tech world"
pros: They like to give employees the chance to spread their wings and branch out, and provide support and training to do so. They treat employees well and there is great diversity, talent, and respect in the workplace. They are doing a great job of not only making sure they aren't being left behind in the tech world, they are actually ensuring that they are putting their efforts into innovation. It is nice to see such a large corporation planning for the future where technology plays a major role.
cons: The corporate structure presents some hoops to jump through with communication.

title: "UW"
pros: Great people, flexible schedules to choose from.
cons: Lacking Technology in uw dept

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Company cares about their employees
cons: Really do not have any.

title: "Best company"
pros: Great place to learn and grow
cons: culture can be a bit slow to adapt to the future

title: "Business Transformation Office - Business Excellence"
pros: Experience the failures and learn from them.
cons: I am not sure if the board had any idea what was going on at the BTO. Nationwide brought in industry experts in lean six sigma from Fidelity, Cardinal, GE, McKinsey, Ford to deploy Lean six sigma at Nationwide. These people left their careers to come Nationwide for this purpose. Results were successful very quickly, the program won a national award in its first year. Guess what happened next, NW brought new leadership to BTO and completely demolished the program with people who has no clue what they are doing. There was not a single person left from the old group. The new team had no strategy or direction. Of course, they eventually failed. So what happened McKinsey came from outside and partnered with IT just to deploy Lean within NW and asked for a blank check. What McKinsey was doing was very basic compared to what the original team was doing. Biggest fault is at HR department. What were they really thinking? What was the qualification of this new team? How is it so easy for Nationwide to be throwing money and waste peoples time?

title: "Member Care Representative"
pros: Engagement with fellow colleagues
cons: Need to know someone to move up

title: "Great place to work!"

cons: difficult to jump paybands for promotions

title: "It’s okay!"

title: "IT Operations Department"

title: "PTO"

cons: Lost all my accrued and carried over PTO when i left. This is illegal in Ca.

title: "I have enjoyed my time here."

title: "A Great Place for B Players"
pros: With a company as big as Nationwide, anyone can find their niche if they network enough. Many opportunities for advancement as long as you're willing to put in your time for years on end. If you want consistency and and pace slightly faster than a government agency, look no further.
cons: As a legacy Fortune 100, the future looks questionable. High variability with workloads, role responsibilities, and management experience from department to department. So many patched up products & processes combined with a culture that prefers keeping the peace over addressing serious market threats is a recipe for disaster. Many will make it out the other side, but the best will will take early retirement or seek out better opportunities.

title: "Nice place to get insurance experience then leave"
pros: Flexible work schedules offered after 6 months-year. Have the option to make time up if needed.
cons: Everything goes off of your brand, have to sell yourself to move up. Mingle, volunteer, have little to no errors with metrics to move up.

title: "Nationwide and its management is about as political and corporate as it gets!"
pros: Pay is not bad. 401-K match is good.
cons: Very micro managed work environment. One yearly goal is to do more with less! No consistency within the management teams. Long time employees treated like rookies. They can talk the talk but can't seem to walk the walk. They place no value in there employees and have no qualms about pushing one out the door.

cons: Bad programs and systems; Limited accountability; No consistency in work processes.

title: "Great company to work for."

cons: Medical benefits are not the best. Limited mobility outside of the major centers of operations.

title: "Good Company"
pros: Flexibility, work from home options

title: "Claims Specialist"
pros: Great CO workers, relaxed environment, okay pay, work from home 2 days a week.
cons: Where to even begin... this is known as either a “insurance puppy mill” or “claims sweat shop”. I’m sure there are others but that’s what I heard. The workload is so unbearable, you get about 10 new claims on Monday and fridays and sometimes during the week. Then about 6 or 7 other days. Don’t forget the other 60-100 claims you already have to work on. This job is almost equivalent to a call center. Managers listen in on calls and will sit with you while you take calls to make sure you’re doing good. Oh, don’t forget the accountability boards. Managers post everyone’s numbers up on the board on your team and you have DAILY meetings to go over those numbers. Don’t have the lowest numbers because you’ll be completely embarrassed during these meetings. If you are actually one of the lucky few doing a decent job, watch out, they will make you take on the workload of those that can’t keep up....

title: "Tedious work for good pay in Des Moines"
pros: Higher pay than many other prospects. 3 months of paid training. Good benefits and vacation accrual. About 10 hours of PTO earned per month.
cons: Repetitive inbound calls. Little room for creativity. Hard to move to a different position despite what recruiters advise. Little room for advancement. Arbitrary quality goals. Weekend work mandatory for new hires for at least 6 months.

title: "Licensed CSR"

cons: Nationwide does nothing for Agency offices

It can be highly frustrating. Communication about measurable quality expectations needs to be more frequent. Health insurance is high deductible and somewhat higher cost per paycheck than I'm used to.

cons: Constantly reorganizing as large firms do. At the end of the day, the company or business unit comes first. Can be a dead end for some people. Conservative and sometimes lacking innovative and academic feeling.

title: "Sr Underwriter"

cons: Company direction lost the value of the employee and became to focused on the LEAN process. It was always a FUN company to work for and at but then new senior leadership became focused on only profit and gaining efficiencies.

title: "Senior Developer"
pros: Great for those who are starting out in their career. Great for those who are ending their career. Great for those who want to work on few projects for longer term, and are ok with things moving very slow. Great culture (at least I think so, my area had a horrible culture, but it may just be the area)
cons: Very slow to make innovative, and impacting changes. There are a lot of people who's jobs are to push paperwork and they slow everything down, and in this day and age companies need to be nimble. Technology Silo's - team members love to keep their knowledge, it makes them feel important, but it hurts the team; Share the knowledge. Typically with most large organizations, you have leaders who make decisions who have no idea what that impact is for those that actually do the work.

title: "Things Could Be Better"
pros: The campus is stunning and the amenities are pretty decent. The company is a strong supporter of being who you are (most of the time). The company honors our service men and women. The workforce is mostly composed of some truly amazing people. The pay is ok. There are a lot of corporate discounts/perks.
cons: The benefits are awful. I appreciate that we have any benefits at all, but they need to take a look at health plans and make sure to diversify their offerings. While there is plenty of opportunity for upward mobility, you will only get if you know someone. Nationwide is big on nepotism. I cannot tell you how many times I have heard the phrase, "it's all about who you know." Their expectations of claims staff is outlandish, and the pay is only marginally better that mediocre.

title: "Nationwide Insurance"
pros: Friendly environment, helpful Associates, very competitive salaries, great benefits.
cons: No cons that I can think of at the moment.

title: "Was an amazing company a few years ago"

cons: Claim load,QA expectations,some managers,fear that they are always reducing their employees,claims matrix

title: "Great culture. Work is OK."

title: "Manager IPSO  Stay away!"
pros: Cafeteria is not too bad.
cons: Absolutely a terrible work environment. There were new executives and they were completely lost in this area. Kept piling on underwriters and case managers, spending money and eventually lost the leader of underwriting to a competitor. There was not any open dialogue going on, so forget about discussions, disagreements were frowned upon. Everybody talked behind each other. Most of the work is transactional, so it is not challenging or interesting. Most work can all be automated but there is a huge fight between IT and business units across Nationwide. There is very little self service for life insurance and annuity products. It acts as a backend processing unit for the sales organization. There is a small CI team with a smart manager that is underutilized.

If you are a young and driven career oriented person...stay away . If you are a current tenured associates.... congratulations , you can just show up and collect a pay check.

title: "Agent"

title: "Claims"
pros: Decent salary, 401k match, some pretty good perks with corporate discounts. Company does provide a good amount of resources financially to grow your knowledge.
cons: Large overhead spent on pointless leadership positions. Never seen a company work someone with endless tasks. Management never owns up to try and streamline. It’s the ‘yes sir’ company. Lack of communication from all leadership. And now the layoffs because of the large salaries of leadership, which has created an adverse work environment for the ‘worker bees’. HR is useless in protecting anyone but themselves. Endless spending on marketing versus fixing the broken glitches in systems which would actually save them more money than cutting people. They’d rather just outsource everything (and they have in droves), instead of building a stable, productive, and fun work environment. This is just a small taste...toxic environment is spreading and will ultimately be a big negative on a lot of people. Watch out if you join ‘The Nation’.

cons: For the last 5 years of my employment at Nationwide they were always in a state of reorganization. Every department at every level was constantly under the threat of being reorganized and often what was created was lowering the pay grades and reducing the number of people on the team. So you could make it through the reorg and be asked to stay and your earning power peaked or you would be asked to leave and take your severance and talents elsewhere. Not a pleasant environment to work in.
