The chances of getting to a leadership position are slim to none without leaving the company first. Senior Leadership is absolutely weak all around the company. Only interested in meeting goals, not success.

title: "Good for average"
pros: There are lots of pros and the culture is very relaxed.
cons: All growth is experienced/time based. I have never seen a merit based promotion come quickly.

title: "Claims Adjuster - Commercial"
pros: Company has great employees and managers who support growth within the company. For the most part there is usually opportunity to grow within the company.
cons: Company recently doing some lay offs in certain areas. Health insurance is expensive and not good.

title: "CSR personnel lines"
pros: Great company, great benefits . My supervisor and trainer were awesome . Would go back if ever had the chance
cons: Had to work weekends, pay could of been a little bit more, but they care about their employees. Back to back calls

title: "Nationwide is a great place to work!!!!"
pros: PTO, Flexible days off, Bonuses, Health Insurance, Employee Assistance Programs, Work from Home available.
cons: Schedules are based on tenure more than anything, some members of Management are clueless as to how things work!

title: "Customer service"
pros: Very family friendly environment
cons: No cons really to provide

title: "Operations Leader"
pros: Work and family life balance; ability to work from home in some roles
cons: HR Recruiting not helpful to current associates seeking new positions

title: "This is your dream employer!  If you just want to be very average."
pros: Benefits are great and very little is actually expected of you in term of actual performance.
cons: Upward mobility is very difficult if you are not of an "uncommon demographic." No other way to say it.

title: "Auto Processor"
pros: Flexible schedule, They are a great company to work for. A lot of resources to learn and grow with. I really enjoyed working there
cons: None that I can really think of. Everyone there was very professional and friendly. They did a lot of coaching to make sure that expectations were being met.

title: "Overall a great company"
pros: Fair and reasonable. Appreciate and support associate growth.
cons: Large and ever changing organization, may be difficult to navigate and thrive for some people.

title: "Great organization"
pros: Benefits are what you would expect of a large company, HSA, 401k, pension, dependent caycare account, educational assistance.
cons: Like any large company, advancement can largely depend on who you know.

title: "Sr. Underwriting Assistant"
pros: Lots of team building exercises which are out of the normal spec of work. Scottsdale Insurance (before NW took.over fully) was absolutely amazing! Many additional benefits like free underground parking, much potential to move up and balance of work/life.
cons: NW just thinks of you as a number. Very "corporate". At the end, management were dropping like flies which made for an uncomfortable environment. Disappointed with management.

title: "Customer Service Rep"
pros: A lot of training and good pay for the type of work. Call center environment can be draining Good health insurance and PTO
cons: A lot of opportunity for growth “in theory” but never seem to have open positions Changes happen often and quickly some for the worse

title: "On your side"
pros: Great company with a great culture
cons: Nothing bad to say I love it

title: "Medical Claims Consulting Specialist"
pros: Interesting, variety, able to work autonomously
cons: Currently role is not of value to organization

title: "Executive"
pros: Great breadth of opportunities, good people, competitive compensation
cons: Poor change management, constant reorganization , ivory tower mindset

title: "Fire & Theft Auto Claims Adjuster"
pros: Ability to move up in the corporate structure, they have mentor programs to help you achieve your goals. Health insurance is very poor.
cons: In the claims environment there is too much favoritism between management and friends on their teams. The director allows this to the detriment of a team spirit. The work load is above average with massive field rep lay offs and people are being told that they just have to work "smarter", overtime is very limited if given at all.

title: "Strong Culture"
pros: Team of specialists model works for distribution.
cons: Location is downtown, and have to pay for your own parking.

title: "Property & Casualty Sales Agent"
pros: Good inter-department communication. Good training support and paid licensing. Positive work atmosphere for the most part. Encourage inter-department transfers if you are not feeling a particular role.
cons: Have recently change their quality review process to be way too strict and detailed so they could 1) higher less policy review personnel and, 2) use your quality scores to withhold bonuses, withhold advancement, and use as a means of justifying letting people go easier (has to be 90% or better to "pass", so miss more than 1 of 30 or so points, and you fail basically).

title: "Claims Manager"
pros: Great company benefits 401K, healthcare, associate support
cons: Current leadership and management style

title: "IT specialist"
pros: Very nice and friendly working environment. The supervisor encouraged me to learn and explore.
cons: The team communication need to improve

title: "They try hard to be more than they are."
pros: As a 1099 employee at a local p&c I run my own business and make my own schedule. You make you own success.
cons: The broker dealer is not as sophisticated and able to handle more advanced cases from a product solutions standpoint. Fortunately I have access to 3rd party insurance and investment solutions. The research and marketing for investment services is almost non existent.

title: "Licensed Property and Liability Agent"
pros: Great Underwriters, staff, core values, and training
cons: Mother nature is the only con; hurricanes, tornado season etc. be prepared to work diligently and file a lot of claims as quickly as possible.

title: "Marketing Specialist"
pros: Good opportunities for career development.
cons: Home office associates not very interested in making remote associates feel included.

title: "Best job in the world"
pros: I go to work happy and grateful. Everyday. I got hired with the James R. MacRae agency in Virginia (NW Exclusive Agency) and have been there for over a month. I got hired with no sales experience. And at the age of 19. I was given a chance that I wouldn’t be able to find anywhere else. I got my P&C license within 14 days of being hired, all payed for by my principal agent. He is the most down to earth understanding boss you could ask for. Corporate side of things, Nationwide is one of the best companies you could work for. There is so much support throughout the whole company. If you have a problem, there are is a department to call that will solve your problem. Shoutout to IT support. The training offered through the agent portal is outstanding. They set you up to succeed. They give you the tools. It is all about attitude and getting what you put in. Pay wise, amazing with nothing but room for improvement. My agency is one of the top performing agencies for NW (#124 out 4000+) so the commission is GOOD. It is Salary plus commission. And a BEYOND fair base salary at that. It all really depends on the principal agent. If your agency is run by a good principal then you have to try to fail. If you have a sucky one, it may be a little rough but you can succeed. From what I hear working for corporate isn’t bad either. The company as a whole is great. I found my career and couldn’t be happier.
cons: None yet. Will update if any.

title: "Solid but could be better"
pros: Willing to work on career management, invests in people, flexible schedule
cons: Work isn't super interesting, they are behind in a lot of the current technologies, unwilling to go in new directions

title: "IPSO Not a good place to work"
pros: If you like fake nice people who talk behind you, this is the perfect place for you.
cons: - It is not a merit based company. - Everybody is related, all relatives. -Non stop gossiping - Engagement surveys are a joke, you are coerced into giving high scores. - Engagement is about giving doughnuts to employees, treated like toddlers. - Continuous tongue lashing. Having a discussion is frowned upon. - No trust within the organization. - Same mistakes are done over and over, no effort to fix them. It is as if they want you to keep typing the wrong information everyday. -If you have a college degree you are in trouble, any kind of college degree is undesired. - They want you just to smile and nod, they do not want you to think, challenge, discuss, learn or change anything. -Leaders who think disappear all of a sudden without any explanations. - Continuous humiliation. - Don't ask questions or tell your opinion of how things can be done better or talk about any problems. -No accountability at senior leadership level. -Boring job, boring people, boring technology, super boring. -There is no passion in doing something great or special and to make a difference. If you do, you don't fit in. -Very very very very old fashioned - Extremely old fashioned.

title: "Underwriter"
pros: Flexible and great job nviroment and people
cons: Can be overwhelming with rushes. Not organized

title: "Property Claims Adjuster"
pros: Great People and environment. Indoor parking lot. Brand new building. In-house Starbucks. Management open to new ideas. Dynamic workplace. Highly recommend.
cons: Extremely low mobility. Once you’re in this department, will be stuck there for a long time. High turnover. Long work hours when working catastrophe duty.

title: "Nationwide"
pros: Work from home options Great pension plan
cons: Promoting workers just because they are within your circle Company only cares and customers. Will put their employees on the chopping block quick.

title: "Adjuster"
pros: Great company, great culture, free pay.
cons: Pretty liberal politically and it bleeds into the work place.

title: "Bodily Injury Claims Adjuster"
pros: Flex time, work from home for part of your work week. Benefits are decent. Located right at the light rail RTD station (Lincoln Station)
cons: Very little and ever shrinking opportunities for growth. Leadership roles are only extended to external candidates from other carriers. The property damage job opportunities have been eliminated (layoffs in late 2017). Commercial lines job opportunities have been eliminated (layoffs in 2018). This is a numbers driving environment. This company does not care about their employees. Salary is not competitive. High turnover which leads to unstable claim volume.

title: "Great company!"
pros: Flexible with time, fantastic managers in my department
cons: base salary was a bit low

title: "Inside Sales Representative"
pros: Great benefits and networking opportunities.
cons: None I can think of.

title: "Incompetent Leadership"
pros: None, unless you enjoy being treated like you work in a sweatshop.
cons: Everything... expect to work 12 hour days for months at a time, have an unmanageable work load, and constantly be fed crap from leadership.

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Pay, benefits, and work culture.
cons: The customers can be unbearable if you're in customer service dept. Changing stats.

title: "Claims Specialist II"
pros: Ample time off, excellent company culture
cons: Onboarding process, revolving door of management, low pay in comparison to competition

title: "Scrum Master / Agile Coach"
pros: new technology and processes. work and life balance.
cons: limited advancing opportunities. exclusive culture in some LBs

title: "Web Infrastructure Engineer"
pros: Great location in downtown Columbus. Community feeling in a large city. Stable employer.
cons: Doesn't have a strong culture of meritocracy. Who you know is as important as individual and team performance.

title: "Patient Access"
pros: What they stand for and do for children
cons: Nothing at all to complain about

title: "Should be better"
pros: Located in a great suburban location.
cons: It is a very small office.

title: "Nationwide Insurance"
pros: Good benefit package (50% 401k match to 7%, pension). Work/life balance is lived and not just given lip service
cons: It's a big company and you get the accompanying bureaucracy that comes with that. I believe that management tries hard, but some things you just can't tame in an organization with the size of Nationwide and the variety of positions/jobs/people within it that are required to make it go.

title: "Learning and Performance Consultant"
pros: The culture is wonderful and family centric
cons: There is nothing I could say that is negative

title: "Underwirter"
pros: Greta company to work for.
cons: Not really any, they are trying to accommodate all.

title: "Holdays and benefits"
pros: They give you 18 paid days off a year PLUS 9-10 paid holidays a year. Ive never received so many paid holidays anywhere before. New years day, martin luther king day, 2 days for fourth of july. memorial day, labor day, two days for thanksgiving, two days for Christmas.
cons: Some people don't enjoy working for the best company, Or one that truly cares about all of its associates. That's on them though.

title: "Great work/life balance, not the most modern in IT"
pros: Great culture and work/life balance! Tons of opportunity to better your skillset or even train in a completely new field.
cons: Still fairly behind the times when it comes to technology. Also not the most competitive when it comes to attracting millennials.

title: "Consultant,  Process  Management"
pros: Vacation, nice facilities
cons: Paltry raises - typically 1%; poor culture that values perception over accomplishments; unless you are a woman or a neutered male, you won't fit in

title: "admin"
pros: diversity, opportunities for college grads
cons: associates over age 50+ are treated poorly and eventually terminated

title: "First office job"
pros: Good management, cares about employees and their career development. It shows that they care about the opinions of employees
cons: The job could be dry depending your interests

title: "Great Company to Work For"
pros: Great work life balance, great company that cares about the community and their employees.
cons: Hard to think of anything bad.

title: "Claims"
pros: The people and culture are great! They strive to live out the values.
cons: This is a competitive industry and there are always a lot of change to try to stay ahead of the competition.

title: "sales"
pros: pay and benefits are good, work life balance is good
cons: new sherrif in town every few months

title: "Personal Lines Underwriter"
pros: Coworkers are friendly and professional, amenities are hard to beat (gym, cafeteria), endless work groups. 3-4 month training is helpful.. JEANS EVERYDAY
cons: The job became very micromanaged, went from underwriting a small territory to underwriting all 46 states in a matter of 3 years. During busy season you’ll be on the phone the majority of the time while trying to juggle multiple systems (Nationwide/allied/newer system). Unfortunately felt closer to a service center rep than an underwriter

title: "agent"
pros: money and schedule flexibility are good. opportunity to change schedule every few months based on ranking
cons: too many misrouted calls or calls from third party that arent even in the market for insurance who are mad and think you called them

title: "Office manager"
pros: Great company one of the fortune 500 Great team to work with at all times
cons: There is no down side to work in a very good enviroment, with great people and good customers.

title: "Supply Management Services"
pros: Great company with great values! Most team members are awesome to work with.
cons: Leadership lacking in some areas.

title: "Would not recommend"
pros: The job itself it interesting
cons: The department is WAY understaffed. You work long hours.

title: "Attorney"
pros: Work life balance, challenging and interesting work, sophisticated business partners
cons: Consistently under market salaries and serious lack of advancement opportunity, under appreciated by leadership

title: "Director"
pros: Leadership provides frequent communication on business outlook
cons: Large company - sometimes loose that personal feel

title: "Claims Adjuster"
pros: Great pay, work environment, and benefits.
cons: Twelve hour shifts without notice and no estimated end time of twelve hour shifts

title: "Claims Adjuster"
pros: People you work with are great
cons: Unrealistic expectations, they are currently re-organizing, but failing to care about the people. 12+ hour days, fail to take into account travel in work balance. Don't care about customers...its all about the bottom dollar for them. So if you have to travel over 4-5 hours away one way, don't care. you should be able to keep up with the paperwork. No advancement. Never expect a "good job", you will be second guessed on everything you do. Your manager doesn't have your back. High deductible for your medical insurance so don't expect any relief there.

title: "Senior Commercial Lines Underwriter"
pros: Community Oriented Supports Diversity Pension Plan
cons: Overworked employees Unrealistic goals and expectations Constant change in priorities

title: "Maybe good for a first job if you need a ton of hand holding and babysitting"
pros: Great benefits, diverse workplace, outstanding paid training, pretty good office environment, many opportunities for volunteer/charity work, probably a good resume piece for someone early in their career who likes to drink the corporate kool-aid. Management teaches basic team building, motivational thinking and accountability.
cons: Typical corporate office job, you feel like one of a herd. Poorly outdated technology - the interface of the customer service system you're required to work in could be updated/simplified for much less money than they must be spending to tediously train employees on it for 6 weeks. Opportunities to move up are slow - 2 years to gain next level above basic customer service. Management requires you to ask to go to the bathroom and you can't go more than once on your shift - I found this extremely demeaning and inconvenient. For older employees, this would be a deal breaker.

title: "Small Market Underwriting"
pros: Flexible PTO, good life/work balance, manageable workload, team oriented, engagement is valued.
cons: Salary is significantly lower than industry standard, very micromanaged, underwriters are put on a scheduled phone loop, department has turned into more of a call center/processing center based with the goal of grinding out work as opposed to customer serviced based, and production/quality goals are unrealistic and unattainable.

title: "MCR"
pros: i love my co workers and my supervisors
cons: nothing everything here is good

title: "Great place to work!"
pros: Respectful, low-stress culture. Great work-life balance. Genuinely care about employees, promote diversity.
cons: Can be cliquey and insular. Paths upward are poorly defined. Mediocre compensation.

title: "Excellent place to work"
pros: Great place to work at NW
cons: I do not have anything

title: "Commercial Underwriter"
pros: Great work / life balance with a good amount of vacation time. I was lucky enough to have 2 great managers in my time there in claims & underwriting. They are very involved in the community.
cons: Lower industry standard pay for Underwriters.

title: "Call Center Representative"
pros: Nationwide is a diverse and welcoming company for everyone. There are opportunities for internal career advancement.
cons: They can be fickle about how people are promoted internally . Working in the call center is demanding in that the call volume is very high and time isn't given to get away from the phone for employee development, team meetings or even for company events.

title: "Non-Injury Liability Adjuster"
pros: Great company to advance your career.
cons: No work/life balance. Very fast paced and high stress.

title: "Great midwestern insurance company"
pros: Culture is great. Awesome opportunities to get involved outside of your job. Networking is encouraged and taking roles across the company.
cons: ‘Nationwide nice’ gets in the way of getting work done when people agree in the meeting and then disagree with you afterwards.

title: "Awesome"
pros: Casual, good friendly people, smart and passionate. Great work life balance.
cons: Little oppty for growth except in home office

title: "It is what it is"
pros: Continual training. Fast paced environment.
cons: Those who do the job well get to do the work of those who do not. There's been a hiring freeze so when someone leaves the company those who are still there are rewarded with extra work load to dig out the mess the person who left, left behind. Was told "It is what it is" whenever asked why those who stayed with the company were being abused.

title: "Great Company"
pros: They care about the employees. Want to make the job fun.
cons: Call center dealing with angry members because they do not know what they bought

title: "Member care representative II"
pros: The campus was great! I enjoyed my training and i also enjoyed being surrounded by great, fun people! Work was good, i enjoyed it for the most part. Pay and benefits where half decent. Great entry level job or stepping stone. Flexible schedules.
cons: Empolyee retention was very low, I would say 4/16 trainees stayed in a period of 16 months do to the dificulties of dealing with the systems & software. The way calls where being graded was always against you, and they would get you for even the minimal stuff, bunch of micromanagement everywhere. The procedure manual (inquira) was terrible, slow & dificult to work with and to understand (this was a center wide issue) but yet we where expected to always use it regardless if we knew what the procedure was or not, yet we still where expected to always have an Improving call handle time score. They expect perfection yet the salary was medicore at best, so where the benefits. No bonuses and empolyee appreciation was garbage (their idea of a great employe appreciation gift was a tiny tray with a about 25cents worth of queso & some nachos), not to mention we never had a xmas party. Advancements where all about who you know and what you do for them, they called it "networking". The systems we used where dificult to operate and very, very old (looks like something out of windows 98)... Very shameful for a fortune 500 company to use such outdated systems and refuse to upgrade them.

title: "great company to work for"
pros: great company to work for
cons: low salary, but great company

title: "Good company"
pros: Good 401k match and pension contribution, strong emphasis on associate engagement and development, company cares about associates, salaries competitive with industry
cons: A lot of email “noise” related to time consuming corporate training and policies that can interfere with productivity, expense reduction efforts have led to less perks

title: "Agent"
pros: Great line of work if you’re the principle agent. Make your own schedule, everyone needs auto/home insurance. Love the line of work
cons: Pay, closing commercial deals. Very difficult to make a living just starting out. Great industry, just very difficult to earn a base pay as an agent.

title: "Underwriter"
pros: Friendly people, good philanthropy, nice pension benefits on top of 401k
cons: Too much work for too little people, relocation required to one of 6 regional offices, Small bonus structure to 2% , advancements limited

title: "Licensed CSR"
pros: Great Hours and salary income
cons: Be prepaired for overtime during hurricane season or other weather related claims. It's tough, but fun!

title: "Member care representative II"
pros: Work/life balance Compensation Engagement
cons: Ability to move up/through company

title: "accounts receivable"
pros: good benefits and good training options
cons: manager did not work on site

title: "Claim Call Center"
pros: Nationwide is a great company to work for. Many growth opportunities. Only reason why I left was because school. Once I’m done with school I will go back because I want to become a supervisor. They really did make this place feel like home. I personally felt the job was easy. I cannot wait to go back!
cons: -I was working in the auto claims dept so the incoming calls were pretty difficult to deal with due to the fact that people are going to call in upset because their car was damaged somehow. However, just be calm and collective and you’ll do fine. All calls are different.

title: "Good Company"
pros: Nationwide has been very flexible, allowing me to care for myself and my family. Employees are definitely one of the companies first priorities.
cons: They don't pay as well as some of the competitors. While previously, it used to be easy to move around the company, that's proving to be more challenging as of recently.

title: "Accounting"
pros: Flex time Employee benefits Cafe Mobility Training Process improvement
cons: Downtown traffic Elevators Elevators long waits at peak times Downtown traffic

title: "IT/Business Analyst Specialist"
pros: Good salary and flexible work schedule
cons: *Poor executive management. * Reducing staff to higher cheaper labor. *Culture in some business units are not inclusive and if you disagree with the groups narrative you are shunned.

title: "Good Company"
pros: Good company to work for
cons: No negatives sto work for

title: "It was a good ride while it lasted."
pros: There are many growth opportunities.
cons: Left hand doesn't always know what the right hand is doing.

title: "Auto Liability Adjuster"
pros: good opportunity, if you get the right boss you will succeed, great company if you stick it out for 5 years.
cons: unequal pay, management isn't truthful, unfair to some employees

title: "Consultant"
pros: Great company. Good work culture
cons: I don't have any thing tell

title: "AVP"
pros: Free Ramp Parking, cafeteria on-site, conveniently located downtown
cons: Management cliques, very little time to develop personal growth, meetings constantly, managers have duties that take them away from staff development

title: "Human Resources"
pros: Career Opportunities were there for those interested, functionally or cross functionally.
cons: Big company... with big company policies and procedures

title: "Good company but a lot of politics for promotion and internal job switch"
pros: Co-workers are nice and they adhere to agile practices for the most part.
cons: Impossible to get a promotion based on performance. Way easier to just switch to a different higher position (external job, not internal).

title: "Great location and work life balance"
pros: Great location and work life balance
cons: Not enough advancement opportunities to current employees

title: "A Great Company!"
pros: Great Company who cares about the people they employ.
cons: There are none for me

title: "Good Benefits, Stale Environment"
pros: -Very good benefits - they take care of their employees -Good network within the company -Usually not overly stressful outside of certain period (and depending on department, of course)
cons: -A lot of office politics -Only people within a manager's "inner circle" of friends got promoted, in my experience -401k match is just ok -Review process wasn't transparent despite efforts to make it that way -A lot of time lost to meetings or the latest efficiency effort -Environment can be stale

title: "Worst Company Ever"
pros: No pros working for Nationwide.
cons: If you provide customer service they will penalize you.

title: "Administrative Assistant"
pros: Great co-workers, good pay for position, PTO time was decent.
cons: High premium for health insurance considering the extremely high deductible.

title: "HR Manager/Consultant"
pros: Very employee centric, this is definitely a company someone would retire from
cons: Lack of development. It depends on your manager if you get opportunities.

title: "Claims Specialist"
pros: Great Atmosphere Managers will fight you You can work on your own schedule Ability to work from home GREAT benefits Amazing Training
cons: Work load can be intense at times Fast Pace environment, you must be a quick learner Nationwide isn't in every state They sold their subsidiary companies leaving people unemployed

title: "Nice Place to work"
pros: I enjoyed working downtown and I enjoyed my teammates and co-workers
cons: Not the best work life balance

title: "Senior Analyst"
pros: Great work environment and management
cons: Pay is not always competitive related to other employers.

title: "Sr Administrative Assistant"
pros: Nationwide places a lot of emphasis on diversity and inclusion.
cons: Upper management is not in touch with the people who do the actual work, yes people get promoted more quickly.

title: "Great work life balance"
pros: Work life balance sets this company apart
cons: Things do tend to move a bit slower

title: "Sr Consultant"
pros: Good work-life balance, moving within the company encouraged, multiple opportunities to grow
cons: Slow moving and adverse to change. Projects can take so long to launch that they are no longer relevant when complete.

title: "Finanacial services analyst"
pros: i guess the benefits are okay
cons: so many downsides to working in call center

title: "great experience"
pros: good base pay great support team members are super
cons: long hours call center position high health insurance

title: "Too many changes without explanation"
pros: Decent Work environment Work environment used be very good.. with good engagements
cons: Slow Growth Upper management changing a lot of things without reviewing or explaining the benefits of changes Lot of out sourcing

title: "Good Work Life Balance"
pros: Work Life Balance Org Culture Stable Industry
cons: Too many organizational transformations going on at once Can be slow to promote

title: "Big changes but ok place"
pros: Pretty good benefits, cool commercials, volunteer activities
cons: Stressful and lots of change happening right now not necessarily all for the best

title: "Account Executive"
pros: work from home/ benefits resources
cons: anyone can see your territory /salary/leadership turnover

title: "Great Place to work IT"
pros: Great learning environment Plenty of time for family Friendly and Open work environment Great Benefits
cons: Salary is not the best.

title: "Claim Adjuster"
pros: Good Vacation time Pension Some work from home time
cons: Non competitive salary Minimal bonuses Mediocre facilities Unresponsive leardership

title: "Great Work/Home Balance"
pros: Great place to work if you need flexibility with your home life. There are opportunities for advancement if you are mobile and/or work in Columbus. You don't have to be qualified to get promoted.
cons: Work load is heavy and at times overwhelming. Pay scale is below average and increases and bonuses are slight. Evaluations are based on popularity and not performance; managers collectively rate employees and decide final performance ratings. Tenured employees are unappreciated and considered by management to be overpaid.

title: "Nationwide Retirement Solutions- Good experience but i would never do it again- nor would I recommend"
pros: Great benefits and work environment. Minimum wage is 15$/hr which is not bad at all for a starting career. You also get a good amount of paid vacation time. Overtime opportunities.
cons: The financial services representative position is as micromanaged as it gets. they will not hire enough people for the call center which cases just about every working day to bring in back-to-back calls. Upon hiring they insist this call center is not a "sweat shop", however, that is exactly what it has become.

title: "Material damage adjuster"
pros: Pension and 401k, time off is ok and health benefits and HSA are above average, working holidays pay time and half and are worth it
cons: Was shamed into working when my eight month old baby was in the hospital and my husband was across the country. I was runner up for the CEO award and barely got a raise..... manager was emotionally abusive and HR was notified of her sexual harassment remarks. No work life balance at all. Worked many twelve hour days but denied overtime

title: "Personal Lines Sales Agent"
pros: You get what you put in. Great culture, fun, competitive atmosphere. Great engagement with management.
cons: Many changes, bonus metrics changed due to company debt for personal lines agents.

title: "Great people, old infrastructure"
pros: So many really good people, with lots of talent. Very good work/life balance and a good work environment in most cases.
cons: Poor decisions often made at higher levels and a legacy system that is woefully out of date. Projects get funding based on what's sexy and new now, not always what is critical for future growth and immediate need. Overloaded and unhappy employees get asked a lot how they are doing, but don't get help. Poor planning leads to wasted money and layoffs. Management's unique language, "Wide-speak," is unnecessary and confusing for employees in fields other than management.

title: "Great Place to Work"
pros: Collaborative environment with the opportunity to gain cross functional experience
cons: The organization is top heavy

title: "Claims Manager"
pros: Salary and benefits were competitive
cons: Not age or disability friendly

title: "Claims CSR"
pros: Good management and work environment.
cons: This is a call center job.

title: "Claims Manager"
pros: Pay and benefits, flexible work hours
cons: organizational change impacting employee engagement

title: "Nationwide Project Manager"

title: "Started out great, ended being the worst job I ever had."
pros: There are genuine people in the company that really do care about their customers and what they are doing. The ‘core’ of the company which is helping other people is honest and sincere. I have been in elevators with multiple CEOs taking about how even though they had to pay out for storm damage that is what they were there for. Great flextime. Come in when you want as long as the work gets done. Need to make up hours, just do so on the weekend. Sick family member, just go take care of them don't worry about it. You can work with really amazing people and make great friends. Facilities are top-notch for a downtown building(s) (minus Agile spaces.) If they do decide to laid you off they give a generous severance and time to find a new job.
cons: When I started five years ago I was the ‘rock-star’ on the team. I transferred to a new team and everything fell apart after that. You have way too many individuals in managing positions who do not understand the work that their subordinates do, or that are not properly equipped for the task given to them. I have seen several times groups thrown into specific roles with little or no training to maintain the responsibilities given to them. Lean processes are used to remove individuals who speak up against being treated poorly. Don’t like that we remove your wastebaskets, we just ‘lean’ you out. Don't like the standing desks and 'standing' well you're too close minded so we'll just reorg your department without you in it. New buildings are all crowded little cubicles with no walls and no privacy. You have no privacy, none! People will be screaming and laughing loudly when you’re trying to get work done. When you complain managers will tell you to find a meeting room or put on headphones instead of correcting the bad behavior. Too much trying to be like Facebook/Google in the IT space without consideration for those with disabilities. The IT agile methodology does not work and is the downfall of creativity in American society. The constant so-called modernization of the modern office does nothing more to delight the millennial to believe they are being paid more than they actually are, and isolate everyone from Generation X up. No one who actually wants to accomplish something at work enjoys these environments. Most of the day is the younger group standing around getting nothing done while the adults actually are trying to work and getting headaches. Nationwide does nothing to correct or remove employees who have inappropriate or bad behaviors. Someone is allowed to be a complete jerk to you and their supervisors will even support them. Marketing and IT will literally fight over processes to remove employees they don't like. If you don't play the nice game and 'suck-it-up' Nationwide will not be on your side. Office of Associate relations and HR are completely incapable to take care of and assist employees. I attempted numerous times to find a new role within Nationwide and all I received was automated responses. When I finally did receive feedback, it was another case of a manager not knowing the technology or the business need. Nationwide’s Health Benefits plan are extremely disappointing. You are forced to give up your vitals otherwise they will deduct money from your paycheck. Too much process in the wrong areas and not enough trust for qualified employees to do their job, and then over-compensating for employees or are inadequate. A lot of unqualified people get promoted because they can 'walk the walk, talk the talk.' Don’t have a standard family (wife and kids) or belong to a minority group (woman,gay etc..) you won’t fit in. Single people over 40 are also in the firing range for being fired. As typical with most businesses they hire a lot of contractors from external countries who do not know what they're doing. They stay for a while make money to send back to their parents and then leave at the critical time of the project. A lot of talk of transparency and speaking up, but when you actually do you get criticized.

title: "Claims Adjuster"

If you're not full time, you're expected to do the same amount of work with no overtime.

title: "good company to work for"

title: "A Long time employee perspective"

title: "Project Management"
pros: The best reasons to work for Nationwide is that it offers excellent benefits, the autonomous working environment and the fact that it supports community volunteering.
cons: The downside of working at Nationwide is that it is a large company and it can take a long time to get something approved. However, if you know how to navigate those channels to effectively get decision, you will be successful.

title: "Great if You Can Handle the Work"
pros: First and foremost the call centers put training and improvement before all else. You get 3 months of training with the first month you don't take call at all. I couldn't ask for a better environment or co-workers at a call center. Everyone is willing to help each other and you will get to know them. The metrics are important but not absolute. QAs critique random calls and you can email them for an explanation if their comments don't make sense. Supervisors are very open and will take time off if you want to talk to them.
cons: This job just wasn't for me. The customers can be very rude and working for personal auto you'll hear horror stories about accidents and bad claims adjusters. That was too much stress for me and I had to go on long term absence for my mental health. Eventually I realized that the job was not the best fit so I resigned. I wanted to stay with Nationwide but any attempt at changing positions would be difficult and I would have to go back to taking calls, which I knew I couldn't do.

title: "Nice benefits"

cons: They only offer high deductible medical insurance plans. They do a lot of "reorganizing" which can cause a lot of associates to lose their jobs due to closures or restructure of a department.

A spirit of innovation is generally received as a threat to the status quo, not as an asset.

Discounts are amazing... and the the company environment is second to none.

title: "Claims Specialist"

title: "Nationwide Nice = Passive Aggressive Behavior"

cons: Politics are awful and impede progress. Leadership (and other lower-level employees) use Nationwide Nice (i.e., passive aggressive behaviors) to get what they want which doesn't make me think very highly of them.

title: "Process Management Specialist"

cons: Such a large corporation, easy to get lost.

title: "Underwriting Environment"
pros: Good training. Positive management staff, and nice coworkers.
cons: Below average pay for industry. Tries to compensate poor pay with good culture. However the culture is nothing special. Not redeeming at all. They spend a huge amount of money on their marketing and sales teams to promote "growth" however they simultaneously preach that underwriting must become more strict. All this is happening while a lot of folks in underwriting are not receiving any raises in salary (even when promoted, or responsibilities increase) and Sales Managers are receiving bonuses larger than my annual salary. It is a very Sales/Growth driven culture, which is good if you work in that department. If not, I advise you work for another company. This place is where ambition goes to die.

title: "Great company to work for"
pros: Great people, good benefits, fun culture. Work/life balance
cons: Work can be boring. Favoritism. Can get political.

title: "Very solid experience"
pros: Great benefits and leadership. A lot of opportunity if you play your cards right
cons: Like any company it can be very political when it comes to getting new positions or raises. They do tend to pay less than industry average, but they can make up for it with their benefits

title: "Financial Advisor / Business Development"

cons: The agency level is absolutely terrible, disorganized and unprofessional.

cons: A lot of changes are going on right now. This could be good or bad.

title: "Financial Service Analyst"

title: "Great company"

title: "Customer Service"

title: "Sales and Service Advocate"

title: "Nationwide is awesome"
pros: Awesome place to work.People were super friendly.
cons: I cant think of any.

title: "It's a big company that has been and is going through important restructuring and organizational changes."
pros: Due to its size you'll learn and have access to some of the latest software and systems. Your success, growth, and failure is in your control. Some people make it far and others stay where they are at.
cons: Too many and ongoing unnecessary changes in process and workflow improvement mostly because the wrong people get hired into highly technical roles and make decisions they have no technical knowledge about yet have to please the boss.

title: "Best Company"
pros: Good pay, great leadership, excellent facilities, 401k and pension plan
cons: I do not have any cons right now

title: "Casualty Claims Adjuster"
pros: There was flexibility with my schedule. The people I worked with became good friends. Doing the right thing for the customers was the most important thing that was considered in the decision making process.
cons: The work environment became increasing toxic. Work load was the biggest factor that no one in management wanted to discuss. The work load was compounded by the increased micromanagement. Both factors made for long work hours including weekends and it was never enough.

title: "Great Place to Work!"

title: "Change Management needs work in upper management"

title: "Director"
pros: company gives to the community
cons: success depends on who you kno

title: "Senior Accountant"
pros: Flexible, Growth Opportunity, Work/Life Balance

title: "great company to work for"

cons: there is nothing bad i can say about nationwide wish i was still there but moved to texas

title: "Work life balance and great pay- but sometimes discouraged by corporate politics"
pros: For the most part, the people I work with are super nice, great people. The company values life and family outside of work, which is amazing. You're also surrounded by people who have never worked anywhere else (for better or worse), which can feel suffocating at times. They call it the golden handcuffs- it's an amazing place to work, and eventually, you feel trapped and like you can't leave- which, to some, is a good thing.
cons: Like any large company, there's politics to navigate and long/slow processes that come with having thousands of employees who work for one company. Coming from small, scrappy companies in the past, I get frustrated by the people who don't work too hard/have learned to do minimum to get by (which is easier at large companies).

title: "Review"
pros: Flexible work environment; excellent benefits
cons: disconnect between upper management and lower management; no employee professional development

title: "Two Faced"

title: "Sr analyst"
pros: work/life balance, made great friendships

title: "Claims"

cons: long hours, no overtime pay. workload was extreme and not evenly distributed. management was inconsistent. long term employees had first dibs on vacation, in 18 yrs never had extra days around holidays, except last year able to visit family out-of-state during Christmas.

title: "Sweatshop"
pros: Good training ground for your next job

title: "Moving in the right direction"

title: "My experience at Nationwide was a great experience. I learned a lot in my almost 20 years with the company."
pros: The best part of working at Nationwide would have to be the atmosphere and the people. The company was always upbeat.
cons: I wish we would've had more fun outings as a company. Sometimes that helps boost morale for everyone. I also hoped our dress code would be more lenient.

title: "Great Company but don't care about your personal health"

cons: Claims adjusters are over worked and underpaid and any personal illness or family issue is not something they care about.

title: "Specialist"
pros: solid company well established strong business model
cons: long hours Way to many reports and duplication

title: "Director"
pros: Work-life balance, culture of collaboration

title: "Nationwide Experience"
pros: Great place to grow personally. Training and educational opportunities.
cons: Younger folks are favored with more opportunities for promotions in my area.

title: "Financial Services Representative- Retirement Plan"
pros: The best things about this position were it was a 9-5 and you leave work at work. Management also worked hard to keep employees happy by providing free food and team building activities. Good time off.
cons: Dealing with difficult custumers and mandatory overtime

title: "Fabulous Company, Horrible Bully"
pros: Nationwide is a fabulous company to work for. They offer substantial employee benefits and encourage office moral and interpersonal interactions with the team. Corporate was very helpful and I felt like they honestly cared about me as an employee.
cons: Corporate HR was not well versed in addressing inter-office bullying behaviors and inappropriate interpersonal communications that were taking place in the local office environment. VP's and Managing Attorney had no training or experience managing an office bully who had bullied, threatened and intimidated other support staff before my employment, during my employment or after my employment ended.

title: "Manager"
pros: Atmosphere is very inclusive and lots of opportunities for self-development and career advancement within a particular discipline.
cons: Limited opportunities to move into other areas of discipline, not because of lack of opportunities, but because of the mindset of some of the leaders.

title: "Great Company"

title: "Claims Manager"
pros: Great people to work with. Learned a lot about being a leader.

title: "EE"

title: "Great place to work and grow"

The people I work with are all dedicated to doing their best work and the company supports its employees when they want to branch out into other roles. The company also has a vested interest in the community, taking a lead role in both hunger relief in central Ohio as well as United Way.
cons: One main downside to working in the downtown location are the elevators! The population density on the floors is not equally weighted so that some elevators are always busy and some never are.

The insurance company was Allied Insurance until they were bought out within the last 10 yrs and ever since the working culture has changed dramatically. Now the company is huge and it has gone from a nice comfortable company to work for to a corporate environment that is really micromanaged and ever changing, building and tearing down divisions at an ever increasing rate. Not a great job for the independent worker. Heavily micromanaged.

title: "No Sponsorship Available for International Students"
pros: * Flexible hours * Great culture
cons: The state of Ohio is not e-verified. As nationwide has their headquarter here, the company is not e-verified either. So although they can recruit international students, they cannot extend the duration of STEM-OPT. But if your carefully chosen OPT starting date and ending date envelopes the H1B application period, then you have one shot at it.

title: "Good company, good people"
pros: Great people, work-life balance, and community investment. The company believes in and invests in people and career development. Plenty of opportunity within the company to grow and try different things.

title: "Great potential to move up. Management is eh."
pros: Great culture and benefits. You can truly have a great career here. Very inclusive. Great trainers. It has been a really great ride so far.
cons: Pay is not competitive. Managers and supervisors are very stuffy. Moving up is easy but moving your pay up is not as easy as it sounds. Lots of lateral moves.

title: "Fortune Great Place to Work"
pros: Tons of benefits, they still have a pension, supportive work environment (not high pressure), change management communication has immensely improved in the past several years, casual dress
cons: I've been here for 9 years. For 8 of the years I worked for a company that deserved to earn the Fortune Great Places to Work. For one terrible, miserable year, I worked for a place that made me want to gargle razor blades. Your experience at Nationwide is HIGHLY dependent on your specific department and specific manager. A lot of senior leadership is against working remotely for some inexplicable reason. You're expected to climb the ladder one rung at a time, even if you are qualified for higher positions. Management will openly report that it's extremely unusual to skip a pay grade.

title: "Business information Analyst"
pros: - Good learning opportunity to learn about various parts of the insurance business - Work in a challenging environment which can jumpstart a career in insurance - Can obtain a lean six-sigma certification with the period of working there
cons: - Contract system not a great motivation for new hires since not benefits are obtained. - Can be a contract staff for a long period of time.

title: "Good company to work for"

cons: They only have a handful of go-forward locations. If you're not in one of them, good luck.

title: "Communication Consultant"
pros: The folks in the Scottsdale office are extremely talented and knowledgable, a true joy to work with. The legacy and reputation for the old Scottsdale Insurance brand kept agents engaged for the company's entire history. And the company has the nicest customers ever! I enjoyed being matrixed to the larger Nationwide network, having that clout and expertise as resources.
cons: Corporate is taking over more and more of the company management and slowly squeezing out what made this location's work unique and the gold standard in the industry.

title: "MD Claims Adjuster"
pros: Initially training was what you would expect to succeed. Management speaks like they are there to assist and listen. Pay is good but overall my impression is they are below national average. It's a good place where inexperience isn't a factor as long as you have a good spirit and can provide customer service. They provide educational reimbursement if you can find the time to get it in.
cons: Management shifting is all too common and when it happens it's like Russian rhulette on whether you're getting a good manager to help get work done or a 'cleaner'. Company methodology over the past several years was to spend exhorbantly on advertising, refuse promotions and then buy customer indexes through claims which has been increasingly present in their loss ratios for both standard and commercial auto. Hikes in premiums expected to cause loss in claims thus a lesser need for adjusters among other departments. Attrition will fix this.

title: "Customer Service Representative"

title: "Claims adjuster"

title: "Excellent Company to work for"

Pushing issues in a direction without verifying the consequences of those actions is very precarious one. -Nationwide is a large company, things move slowly, once an idea is agreed upon, it takes approval from many many people for anything to actual begin

title: "Great Review"

Senior leadership only cares about how good you make them look and has little regard for the individual contributions of the middle managers and staff. Senior leadership lacks diversity proportionate to the customer base they serve.

title: "Nationwide is a great company to work for."

title: "Bodily Injury II Attorney File Handler"
pros: NW just changed employee dress code to jeans if we choose to wear them. They have also just started a work from home flex schedule on certain days every week that the employee has chosen. They offer a generous 23 days off per year for new employees. They do not micromanage when you are on or off the phone or how long you take for lunch as long as you keep up on your files.
cons: NW has been restructuring the company for a few years now. You never know if your dept may be centralized to Home office even though they do atleast give you 6 months notice. The work load is really high in some depts and not in others resulting in struggles with home/work life balance. The Health Insurance is terrible now. They only offer the high deductible plans when they used to offer the good plans. Some management seems to play favorites.

title: "Sales"

title: "Grate company"

title: "Retention Agent"

title: "Love the overall company, hate the part of the company I work in."

cons: Depends on what office you work in, smaller offices or smaller subsidies are filled with judgement and demotion of qualified employees. Hiring of friends from rival companies. Just overall a hostile work environment

title: "It's okay for now."

cons: Little pay for huge responsibility Older systems constantly have issues Newer systems weren't tested by people who would use them and have many flaws. Weekly changes are hard to keep up with Errors that have been made by someone else could possibly be blamed on you Work from home was dissolved Don't expect to make plans after work because you'll probably work past you "end" time.

title: "IT Staffer"
pros: Many opportunities to learn, try new things. Good focus on education and training. Use of current technology and operating models (Agile, Lean, Dev-Ops, etc.)
cons: Very image-centric. The image you project is at least as important as your performance. Cultivating and managing image can be draining.

title: "Specialist, Business Consultant"
pros: Great company values, Cares about its members and community.
cons: Primarily focused in Ohio, would like to remain with the company, but need to relocate outside of Ohio area.

title: "Great company, great people"
pros: Seemed pretty well organized. Communication was good.
cons: None, I just went in a different career path

title: "Good Culture"
pros: People focus: Smart, collaborative people, positive energy, investment in employee growth, promotion from within, encourages diversity and inclusion. Individual experience depends heavily on the direct manager's style.
cons: Large company, so not as agile, partially bureaucracy and partially just age and size limitations. The top level does recognize this and is investing in improvements.

title: "Nationwide is a great company"
pros: F500 company. Friendly atmosphere and opportunity for growth
cons: There is nothing to write on regarding cons.

title: "Claims Specialist"
pros: Merit based raises every year, company reimburses for education and retirement, work is very specialized you do not have to do a lot of tasks in other areas, field adjusters handle rental and total loss settlements.
cons: health care plan is expensive, not a lot of vacation time, work level can vary, not a lot of positive recognition, management will often forget to take people off claims and put people back on.

title: "Be weary of reviewers.."
pros: Great salary... Great leadership... Great environment.. Great opportunities...
cons: Corporation is large so communication is sometimes delayed... Expansion can be quick in certain areas which results in hiring under-qualified talent.. Must be mobile to be promoted past a certain point.. I've read some reviews on her regarding the company downsizing and that is simple not true. TImes are changing, things are becoming automated, and jobs are transforming into different jobs. In addition, the company was too large to operate sensibly so it did consolidate locations and offer relocation and job placement for those willing to move. Some were not willing to move.

title: "Nationwide - Scrum Master"
pros: They have a very flexible work environment
cons: Many changes that are mandatory that keep people from focusing on their original daily duties.

title: "Good position"
pros: Decent pay, flexible hours, and decent management
cons: Possible long hours, lack of moving up potential

title: "Liability Adjuster"
pros: Great team engagement, managers are actually aware of their teams workload, OT when necessary
cons: Very stressful with the amount of claims, can be difficult to move into other positions that aren't claims related, almost a 1-track career course once you start

title: "Positive environment"
pros: Inclusive, positive environment, great people to work alongside
cons: Large company, communication between departments

title: "Spent over a decade there"
pros: Time off, better then average culture, great people, work life balance. Brilliant dedication to the community and charitable organizations inside Ohio and out.
cons: Pay doesn't even reach industry average, opportunities are based on who you know vs successful performance. Benefits insurance wise are horrible. You can advance by who you know while totally ignoring your role responsibilities. Pay to park in company owned garages. Leaders often are masters of deflecting responsibility to people below them and rarely do you find a leader that supports their people.

title: "Information Technology"
pros: Work life balance is recognized. Strong community supporter of the Food Bank of Iowa.
cons: Limited IT jobs, most have moved to Columbus. No room for advancement. People who seem to do very little in providing value to the organization are treated well as they talk their way into the role. The hard working employees pick up the slack.

title: "MCR VI"
pros: paid time off, co-workers, flexible schedules
cons: health insurance high deductible, typical call center environment, 45 min lunch

title: "Over Rated"
pros: A job for short time.
cons: Nepotism and favoritism rapid. WFH for management causing lack of communication and a negative in training new employees. WFH option given to friends when the volume of work is low for some.

title: "Room for Improvement"
pros: Excellent non-monetary benefits - onsite gym and cafe, EAP, corporate citizenship initiatives. Beautiful campuses with security; facilities are clean with thoughtful floor plans.
cons: Performance evaluations are highly subjective due to lack of appraisal training and concrete, quantitative objectives, computer systems/databases are highly outdated and user un-friendly, no incentive to participate in internships or extra projects, low morality overall due to perceptions of fairness re; compensation and responsibilities.

title: "Non-Injury Auto Liability Claims Adjuster"
pros: fair pay, diverse workplace, fun quarterly engagement events, moderate claim volume, ability to work your way up
cons: regularly shifting work flows and lack of fluid communication with upper management who decides these changes

title: "Nationwide suffers from bureaucracy, but cares about employees"
pros: Cares about employees- flexible to a good work/life balance. Good compensation and work environment. Helpful people.
cons: A good deal of bureaucracy in the inner workings which can be a nightmare to work with. Intense love of time-wasting meetings.

title: "Sales Manager"
pros: Products are good and they are excellent when it comes to paying claims
cons: Very picky who they will insure

title: "Nationwide"
pros: Friendly atmosphere, employee engagement, fortune 500 company.
cons: Understaffed, unrealistic expectations, job responsibilities often times don't reflect job descriptions.

title: "Review"
pros: Very good work life balance. Professional and helpful work environment
cons: Less Challenging and lot of reorganization

title: "Loved my coworkers"

title: "Loss Control"
pros: Overall, good company with caring management that strives to provide a positive work-life balance.
cons: Loss Control is not a first rate operation. Even the most polished consultants will handle mostly small business accounts that generate premium less than $20K. Long written reports with comprehensive service plans are required for even the most innocuous accounts that most other carriers wouldn't even loss control.

title: "Sales Agent"
pros: Fast paced, good salary, good peers, insurance experience, licensing had a great time with training and getting tools I needed to succeed
cons: I didn't thrive in the call center environment and it wasn't the best fit for myself and my career - overtime sometimes didn't fit my schedule

title: "Friendly culture, diverse opportunities"
pros: 1. The people - lots of friendly and caring people. Most people stay at Nationwide for the entirety of their career, which lends itself to fostering not only long-term working relationships, but lasting friendships. 2. The opportunities- it's a large company and if you want to move around and gain experience in different business functions or disciplines you can! 3. Competitive pay, 401k matched up to 6%
cons: Maternity and paternity leave is not good, but there are few companies in the U.S. that offer good leave. Hopefully that changes. Part-time and alternative work schedules are not common

title: "It's ok"
pros: Lenient time off policy andfree access to gym
cons: It is really challenging for one to get out of claims into a different department because those skills are usually not easily transferable. Pay is below market value. Inside adjusters are glued to their phone all day, often understaffed, terrible general health insurance, only matches 50% of your 401k, and only up to 3%

title: "Sr. Pricing Analyst"
pros: Easy going environment. Flexible hours.
cons: Unqualified management. Very low compensation.

title: "Great company!"
pros: Really good benefit packages for full-time employees
cons: Does not provide competitive salary or opportunities

title: "Awesome Company"
pros: I loved that I had a stable income, with infinite compensation opportunities. Very well organized, to not hit your sales goals you must not be trying.
cons: I had left because the over all culture changed. We were once able to sell and talk to potential customers like our friends and take our time with each new caller. We were given call flows and scripts I immediately left. It took away my control over my sales.

title: "Title"
pros: great work to life balance.
cons: not the greatest paying job

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Slow paced work, lots of net working, plenty of space to move throughout company
cons: Work can sometime be a little too slow, as an intern you never have enough work to keep you busy.

title: "Sales Agent"
pros: Good atmosphere Good pay Good benefits
cons: too many changes in sales goals, sales pitch and commission structure

cons: Nationwide has a methodical, intentional approach behind every action. This slows down pace to allow/ensure quality and alignment, but requires an adjustment if you're unaccustomed to this speed.

title: "Consultant"
pros: Company actually cares about their employees.
cons: No turn over, people have been there forever and do not want tot change.

title: "Great place to work"
pros: - The benefits are pretty good - Most of the people are extremely easy to work with and willing to help you further your career - Work/Life balance is important to the company (Most roles are not expected to work more than 38.75 hours/week) - Gym on-site - Management is competent and helpful
cons: - The pay is just average for IT roles

title: "Overall experience was great"

cons: Hours are not very consistent

title: "Program Management"
pros: Nationwide has a solid delivery methodology and mature program management office
cons: I do not have any

title: "Not That Great"

cons: Lack of Communication among team members; horrible management; horrible benefits

title: "Health Insurance is very expensive"
pros: Very people focused. Encourage career advancement and movement within the company. Career mentors and career development readily available upon your request and engagement. Work/life balance is also a plus. Very flexible work environment.
cons: Very expensive health insurance. High premiums and high deductibles. $500+ family premiums per month for health and dental. $3000 family deductible and $7000 max out of pocket. Despite high premiums and deductibles, the coverage is very selective and minimal. Have to fight with insurance for hours upon hours to understand coverage and why certain things are not covered.

title: "Sr Business Consultant"
pros: Culture, People, Flexibility, Development and Training
cons: Minimal opportunity for upward growth due to consolidations

title: "Incredible Company"
pros: Commitment to community engagement, professional development, opportunities for growth and promotion, programming and activities, regular communication from executives, discounts events and attractions, tuition reimbursement and associate incentives
cons: I don't have any cons to share. This really is a wonderful company.

title: "Company Environment"
pros: Good culture and promotes to do lot of professional growth
cons: Processes not streamlined very hard for anyone new to work efficiently

title: "Member Care Representative II"
pros: They are a charitable company that participates in giving back to the community and less fortunate via various nonprofit organizations.
cons: Years of service with the company are not acknowledged or rewarded. I was a tenured employee and it was not considered in shift bidding.

title: "Generally A Good Company To Work For"
pros: Strong financial position, advancement opportunities
cons: Strategy of Company is lacking

title: "Awesome work life balance and honest culture, hard to move up"
pros: Some insanely smart and great to work with people in the investments, risk management, and strategy divisions. 9-4:30pm culture in most other departments. Excellent for work life balance or raising a family.
cons: Giant fortune 100 company. Lots of bureaucracy. Like most companies, 80%+ of works is repetitive. Hard to innovate at a giant corporation with 5 stakeholders across 3 departments needed to sign off and get a button approved on an app (exaggerating obviously but you get the point). When I left in 2013 I felt like alot of jobs/departments were semi-duplicative, hopefully they fixed it with their re-org.

title: "Its alright"
pros: its a good place to work and there is a lot here for people. They offer volunteer opportunities and there are also very good associate tools. pay is okay, benefits are average
cons: opportunities are hard to come by. everything is very political. raises are not very high and cost of living is not a factor in them. Time off carry over is only 5 days and no longer ten.

title: "Property Claims Specialist II"
pros: They are good about paying their claims.
cons: They do not pay overtime and the work cannot be done with a 40 work week.

title: "Customer Service Representative I"
pros: Nationwide is great company, a lot of great benefits. I have no complaints very great company to work for!
cons: I have no complaints.

title: "Attorney"
pros: It is a great place to work
cons: Internal reporting requirements can be excessive

title: "Customer Service"
pros: People were great to work with!
cons: Management was not very progressive

title: "Nationwide? Not so much."
pros: Nationwide provides nice benefits at a reasonable price. Additionally, the company provides very stable work for their full time employees.
cons: Company is excessively Columbus, Ohio centric. If you want any chance at growth, you'll need to move there. For a company that calls itself Nationwide, its view is entirely too limited.

title: "Cyber Underwriter"
pros: Great management & opportunity to grow
cons: Working for a big name like nationwide can sometimes lead to internal restricitions

title: "Walk away."
pros: You will receive a bonus.
cons: You are treated like a toddler, you are forced to take tests to move on or to receive a promotion and being treated equally is not or ever going to happen. Please be aware if you are 10 seconds over you lunch break because of having to use the restroom, you are in trouble. If you do not take the Series 6, you are shunned. And lastly, if you do not take as many calls as you physically can, you get deducted from the "score card". Trust me, its a prison.

title: "Investment manager"
pros: Challenging work environment. Good team work with collaborative colleagues. Good pay for the area.
cons: Bureaucracy sometimes get in the ways of getting things done.

title: "Went downhill"
pros: Worked at pet insurance subsidiary. It was great before Nationwide took over all operations.
cons: Once Nationwide took over VPI Pet Insurance, they slashed benefits and made pets priority zero. Also, Denver office in particular a toxic and backstabbing environment.

title: "DO NOT WORK FOR THIS COMPANY"
pros: flexible shifts food days tuition reimbursement casual dress code laptops
cons: Working for this company was okay for my first week of employment. After that i was placed on mandatory overtime for the entire time I worked for this company. Some have worked here for 7 plus years and have stated they have been on mandatory overtime (10plus hours) since they started as well. Nationwide decided to close down all non standard locations and told us one week before Christmas we will be without a job. Merry Christmas to us! Management is beyond shady and find any reason to put you on an action plan to fire you if you challenge them in any kind of way (like questionable their management skills) Management has no idea how to do the work, but is so numbers driven quality doesn't matter and its ridiculous. The employees aren't very friendly but I understand since we are not allowed to talk to each other during our work day, we are confined to our desks.

title: "Claims Associate"
pros: Nationwide is a great company to work for. The benefits package is the best I have seen. The workload is manageable. You have a lot of tenured people and there is always someone with a wealth of knowledge to answer any questions that you might have. You can gain experience in cross training and it is a great first job out of school.
cons: Only downside is there is very little room to grow. Once you are an adjuster- it is near impossible to become a manager. It takes at least a decade of experience to move higher up. You can make smaller moves laterally but as far as management goes, that is a tough challenge. Another con is the raises are not great. They are minimal at best. The goal sharing makes up for this a little bit. The salary isn't great but again its a good first job out of college.

title: "Underwriting Specialist"
pros: "Nationwide nice" atmosphere. Great co-workers.
cons: Salary compared to competitors. Cost of Benefits.

title: "Direct sales agent"
pros: The trainer was a great guy and the facility was brand new state of the art.
cons: The computer system was prehistoric for such a huge co.and the payout commission was aplorable you had to use your own time to "fish" for policies that were never credited to you.Horrible experience.

title: "Field Claims Specialist II"
pros: Nationwide was probably the best company I've worked for. The support from management, the team, and even the pay was really good.
cons: Needs more adjusters for the high claims urban areas.

title: "National Sales Solutions"
pros: Opportunities for advancement if you work hard.
cons: Management takes little or no interest in employees. Leads are of poor quality. Micromanaging done on a broad level.

title: "IT Specialist - Des Moines Location"
pros: Flexible work schedule (in IT), great team members.
cons: Managers change about every 1-2 years - so new directives, expectations, etc. which make it very difficult to make any progress in improvements to the area. It seems we re-invent the wheel every couple of years. Reorgs occur very often.

title: "Manager"
pros: This company rocks! So proud to work for Nationwide!
cons: None! This company is the best!

title: "Review of Co."
pros: The atmosphere at the office I'm at is great
cons: There seems to be a lot of politics

title: "Worst job ever"
pros: The company is solvent, and there are some really wonderful folks who work there.
cons: I was overworked, underpaid, understaffed, overstressed. Really taken advantage of. Exploited.

title: "IT architect"
pros: Great culture, professionals working in each area makes a great learning experience.
cons: Nothing I can find, its a great company.

title: "A great place to work!"
pros: Well defined roles, great career opportunities!

title: "Manager, IT Applications"
pros: Stable work environment, commitment to improvements in IT
cons: Internal advancement and pay smaller than those coming in externally.

title: "Nationwide Review"
pros: The employee pay is very good
cons: They eed stronger management systems

title: "Great Place to work"

title: "Software Developer"
pros: Flexible work hours, low stress environment, agile development. Good work/life balance

title: "Good"
pros: Employee benefits are awesome here!

title: "claims adjuster"
pros: great company great people great management
cons: downsizing and they seem to be getting out of persona lines, and switching to commercial, so they are selling a lot of their personal lines business.

title: "Nationwide"
pros: Work life balance is a plus
cons: Very political like many companies. Its not about the skills and experience its about who you are friends with. Do not ever leave and go to work for someone else. Unless you are friends with the right people you will not ever be hired again.

title: "Lots of room for growth"

title: "Quality Assurance Analyst Internship"

cons: too much downtime, there were times during my internship where weeks at a time some system would go down and we would have to sit in the team space doing nothing because work was literally incapable of being completed

title: "IT helpdesk"

cons: Huge company, can get lost, went months without talking to my supervisor, little training or time for new skills.

title: "adjuster"
pros: good solid company, been around for a long time

title: "Communications Consultant"
pros: Decent salary, good benefits and a great place to work if you have kids (if you don't have kids-you'll be expected to pick up the slack).
cons: It's a very old-boys club and you will find that men will grow at s much faster rate--although they have a few cases of promoting women in key roles and they will point to these situations over and over again. It's also a culture that heavily depends on HR and will regularly get bogged down in paperwork for no apparent reason and costly meetings with no purpose. I'd say at least 50 percent of your contact with your manager will including completing HR tasks, which leave little time to focus on your work. This ultimately drives down your HR scores.

title: "Nice place to work"
pros: Job movement and development is encouraged
cons: Bureaucracy can cause delays and hinder development

title: "Excellent Company!"
pros: People - Very welcoming and caring
cons: Still under the process of transformation

title: "Employee Engagement"
pros: Great culture. Great work/life balance.
cons: Too many people doing the same thing. Money could be saved be eliminating some of this duplication.

title: "Filing tech data entry"
pros: Work from home! Great team & benefits!
cons: None it's a very great place to work!

title: "run insurance agency"
pros: strong brand and strong values
cons: continuous change creates very uncertain environment

title: "Customer Focused"
pros: Nationwide is actively investing in their long-term success.
cons: Poor HR associate assessment rating system.

title: "Greatness for Entry Level"
pros: Overall there's little to complain about working for a company that 'Values Fun". The leadership is great, the pay is decent, and the possibilities for advancement are numerous.
cons: Benefits could be a little better, specifically talking about the HIGH deductible health plans here.

title: "Great company to work for"
pros: Engaged workplace, never felt like a number. My personal relationship building skills flourished in their workplace.
cons: Very conservative, pay is less than what I would have liked, but exeperience is rewarded.

title: "Commercial Lines Specialist"
pros: Nationwide has a thiriving culture. It's ideologies carter to millennials because it offers work at home opportunities and a great work life balance.
cons: I worked at two different nationwide offices, one of them being the Trial Division office. The Trial Division offices are very high stress.

title: "Good place to work"

title: "Material Damage"
pros: flexible schedule, good work life balance
cons: large workload, sometimes too much

title: "Great Company to work for!"
pros: This company is great and has awesome benefits. Plenty of Growth opportunities and learning curve.
cons: Not enough concentration on what the associates want.

title: "Great company values"
pros: The values that Nationwide exhibits is unusual in my experience. They encourage associates to become involved in many community activities, to work at food banks, and donate blood. Also, in most cases they really seem to take an interest in doing right by associates.
cons: Pay could be better. Terrible review process where managers level their employees against other employees.

title: "Tough start"
pros: Brand name that is very recognizable to consumers, public marketing via TV, some helpful underwriters to work with
cons: Very difficult to write policies as Nationwide is very strict about who they will and will not accept, when I was hired I was brought on fresh from receiving my license and never trained in the office and written up for not meeting "quota" my second month in (while also never receiving appropriate tools such as the obvious - business cards, not allowed to purchase my own either - leaving me looking unprofessional. Feel I was set up to fail.

title: "Great Company - Opportunity to Grow"

cons: In claims, sometimes you speak to customers who are unhappy. Being mobile is important if you want to continue to move upward.

title: "Case manager"
pros: easy job, good peers to work with, good entry level job
