title: "Claims manager"

If you have a family and a family life and want to keep it stay away from Nationwide. Believe me, they are not on your side as a company. Many self centered ego maniacs only looking out for their own self interests.

title: "Specilist - IT Application Dev"

Very demanding work load. As a trainer you should expect long hours . Salaries are lower than you may expect. Only option for health benefits is a high HSA account.

title: "Underwriter"

title: "Claims Specialist"
pros: This company cares about their associates and furthering careers. It has a great culture with wonderful coworkers.
cons: The process can be selective though about who they help progress. The management styles are all very different and while you are doing the same job another team may have many more opportunities due to their manager.

title: "When times are good, they're good but when times are bad..."
pros: Flexible work hours when you are salaried employee & depending on who your manager is. I do not believe that most managers are "clock watchers" especially with salary employees. Pay seems to be in line with other insurers for the most part. Most employees seem happy or at least content with their jobs. Volume of work depends on your department. The office I work in is very friendly and social. Lots of baby showers, happy hour after work, etc...which is nice. Upper management in my office is very approachable; a genuine interest is taken in the employee. Upper management is actually sincere and not the "fake" nice that can occur just because they have to make nice with the huddled masses from time to time just to keep up appearances. When you do your job well, show up for work as required and have no "issues", things will be just fine. Internal job opportunities/transfers are pretty plentiful if you want to move across disciplines or move up in the company.
cons: Depending on your job, staffing in your department & whether or not you're salaried or not, you could technically work less than 40 hours per week or you could work 60+. Benefits such as health insurance have declined over the years. Company has a "wellness program" and if you don't participate you're essentially penalized by paying a surcharge on your health insurance contribution; in addition, you have to meet certain health related goals such as BMI. Performance evaluations always seem to land at a "3" (scale of 1-5, with 5 being the best) for nearly all employees; regardless of how well (or how poorly) the employee performs. My personal opinion is that your performance evaluation is somewhat of a popularity contest. I have had extremely high, glowing evaluations from one manager/region. However, I've been transferred to work under a different manager for one reason or the other, doing the exact same job, performing at the same high level yet I will receive an average ("3") rating. This is not just isolated to me as I have confirmed with others who have faced the exact same issue. It seems illogical that a high performer would suddenly become just average for no apparent reason. I have seen high performers under one manager go to being fired once his/her direct manager changed. Promotions have taken a turn for the worse. You will sometimes see qualified individuals promoted to let's say manager. On the other hand, individuals gets promotions and it leaves us all dumbfounded how someone with no technical skills and no people skills rises to the next level. Perhaps it is the "Peter Principle" in action. Unfortunately, I find all insurance companies to be financially driven (which makes sense) and really every employee is disposable in the end. Like most other insurance companies, Nationwide is a good place to work when everything is good including your health. However, if you become seriously ill/injured, look out. Everything is ERISA so the employee essentially has few rights and little to no recourse. Corporate (those downtown in The Towers) don't know you, don't care to know you and if you're a liability...the balance sheet must be adjusted. Things are made as difficult and cumbersome as possible. To corporate, you (the employee) are just a drain on resources and a financial liability to be reckoned with.

title: "I.T. developer"
pros: I was employed 9.5 years there as a software developer. In terms of technology, Nationwide is top notch. Good opportunities for education. In the area where I worked, office politics was almost non-existent and managers were straight-forward. There were no surprises in the semi-annual performance reviews, however, getting a GREAT review is nearly impossible according to the rubric they use (think "able to leap tall buildings in a single bound"); so an average performance review at Nationwide is fantastic anywhere else. Lots of opportunities to advance and move around the company. When they laid off anyone in our area (which is to say, I don't know if this is company-wide behavior), they told us that we would be receiving our 60-day notice about 30 days in advance. Once we got our 60-day notice, our job was to find a new job. Still had all of the benefits during that time. Severance pay was one week per year of service. Decent pension, if you work there long enough.
cons: Nationwide's I.T. strategy is to move software development off-shore as much as is possible. For those positions which cannot be moved to off-shore, they bring Indians over here to be the interface for the devs back home. Nationwide's partner in crime is Infosys. As we trained our incompetent replacements, we saw all of our hard work flushed down the toilet when they decided to hard-code *everything* instead of using our table-driven "code". Our manager was disgusted, her manager (and, probably, upstream managers) saw only dollar signs. In the end, this move will end up costing the company more in the long run, with far, FAR worse quality and unmaintainable code. Que sera, sera.

title: "Customer Service Representative"
pros: Great coworkers, management that cares. Benefits and pay.
cons: Working in insurance takes a certain kind of attitude when dealing with customers. be prepared to deal with unhappy customers facing their toughest times.

title: "Investment Analyst"
pros: Work/ life benefits, flexibility, engaging, cares about culture
cons: Limited options to move up

title: "Administration"
pros: Great Benefits and retirement plans
cons: Too many old policies and too many politics

title: "Great place to work and live."
pros: We truly are a great place to work and we continue to get better. I most appreciate the people, company values, community commitment, opportunity to learn and earn, positive sense of future, safe environment, attention to work/life balance and desire for greater diversity.
cons: Large company sometimes brings complexity, the need to navigate through layers, and the opportunity for more/improved communication. This can definitely be a turn off for some individuals.

title: "Claims Customer Service Rep I (CSR I)"
pros: Nationwide is an amazing company to work for and there are a ton of great managers and employees. Everyone is very supportive from the beginning and you undergo an extensive amount of training to make sure you are prepared for your job. The culture and environment are the best part about working for Nationwide.
cons: The call center environment just was not for me. I came in at a time when managers where changing quite a lot and communication was not the best on updates to policies. I feel this is normally not the case, though.

title: "Nationwide"
pros: Really Great Benefits and Co-Workers
cons: Not much room for growth within the position I am in

title: "It depends on an individual perspective. Here's my opinion:)"
pros: Good work life balance, friendly and approachable work culture, great benefits and well-recognized brand
cons: Workload is inconsistent and not fast-paced/challenging. It can be a pro for some and con for the other.

title: "Extremely passive-aggressive culture"
pros: Nationwide generally offers competitive salary and benefits. The opportunities to give back to community are varied and available.
cons: The culture has long been a passive aggressive one that has only gotten worse over the years. They actually have named it "Nationwide-nice". They are nice to your face but vicious behind your back regarding business decisions, personal growth and opportunities. It is a brutal environment.

title: "Insurance"
pros: Great locations and people you work with
cons: No flexible hours local management

title: "President"
pros: Great Atmosphere and Location - Computers ect
cons: None at this time long hours

title: "Claims CSR"
pros: It's a good starting point. Lots of room for growth
cons: Schedules can be difficult to change

title: "Commercial Underwriter"
pros: Solid work environment with quality people
cons: Communication level between agents and underwriting

title: "Senior Server Analyst"
pros: My team has a good team atmosphere.
cons: can't move up unless you are in the home office. Benefits are not great.

title: "A good place"
pros: Company cares about associate engagement, provides a generous benefits plan including a bonus and fitness center, good amount of vacation days, and many opportunities to network through associate resource groups and events. Associates can wear jeans all the time (except when meeting outside partner and higher execs)! Taking a lunch or a coffee break is encouraged. Hours can be flexible and associates can work from home to accommodate a variety of circumstances.
cons: Best person isn't always promoted first due to politics. Some arms of Nationwide are sort of invisible, which can be an issue when interviewing in another area. Moving up pay bands is almost impossible in some areas.

title: "good balance work/life schedule, not great management"
pros: Good flexibility in schedule, no micro managing
cons: No transparency, management constantly misleads employees.

title: "Great Place to work"
pros: I worked at the inbound call center, I never had a complain about working there other than the occasional disgruntled customer being rude. Great pay, amazing benefits. Paid time off. Paid training. Wonderful communication with Management.
cons: Wasnt easy to change shifts, you had to put in for shift bids. But other than that I had a great experience

title: "Commercial Claims Analyst, III"
pros: People are nice. Compensation is ok.
cons: It is the most micromanaged process driven company that doesn't allow their experienced and seasoned employees to do their work. Everything is a priority. Old school insurance mentality that.motivates by fear. Wouldn't recommend Nationwide to anyone that has experience. It is the most stifling atmosphere and I regret ever coming to work here. I can not wait to get out of here.

title: "Analyst"
pros: I feel they really care about their associates and members
cons: Parking is a pain and not much maternity leave given.

title: "Lots of change"
pros: Overall culture is strong. Working to become true Middle Market carrier. Have mostly had managers that seemed to care about me. Does a great job promoting from within, showing lots of advancement opportunities.
cons: Trying to too many changes at the same time. Have Completely disrupted agency relationships. With all the changes made it seems that there is currently a lack of direction. With that, will be a force to be reckoned with in 3 to 5 years.

title: "Nationwide"
pros: Large organization with conservative mindset which can lead to a more stable work environment if you are comfortable with the status quo and uncomfortable with change.
cons: Leadership can be somewhat inconsistent due to upper level movements within the organization making it challenging to accomplish goals.

title: "Sr Analyst, Business Consultant"
pros: Wonderful company to work for.
cons: You can find it hard to grow in some positions.

title: "Analyst"
pros: It is a good company. 401k contribution is good.
cons: Did not see anything negative

title: "Associate Commercial Underwriter"
pros: Excellent Training. Very detailed information that other carriers tend to benefit from.
cons: Job climate was unstable there.

title: "Agent"
pros: Independence, flexible hours, good claims response
cons: Company needs to communicate more and have month end numbers quicker

title: "Application Enhancement Coordinator"
pros: Great company to work for and benefits are wonderful.
cons: Always changing vision of the company and everything three to four years does job eliminations.

title: "Great company"
pros: Plenty of opportunity for development.
cons: Sometimes a disconnect between front end employees and upper management.

title: "Project Management Specialist"
pros: benefits and ample time off, even when just starting out
cons: work/life balance can be poor depending on position and manager career development lacking

title: "Quality Assurance analyst Intern"
pros: A great and friendly working environment.
cons: You need to be more self-motivated.

title: "Nationwide"
pros: Good benefits Work life balance
cons: Sometimes limited flexibility on movement

title: "Personal Lines Service Rep"
pros: Nationwide is a great company
cons: There weren't really any negatives

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Very into helping you get promoted, can move around company in as little as 6 months
cons: Management can be strict at times

title: "Underwriting, CL"
pros: Good hours, freedom to work without restraints, great 401k and health, good people to work with
cons: Salaries are underpaid, minimal advancement unless in position more than 2 years, high health deductible plans, not enough vacation hours

title: "Claims adjuster"
pros: Great benefits. Great people. Great company to work for if you are mobile.
cons: The job can be a little stressful at times.

title: "Pluses and minuses"
pros: Overall a good company to work for.
cons: A lot of politics involved in promotions.

title: "Subrogation Specialist"
pros: Great benefits, lots of room for growth.
cons: Sometimes can be very political.

title: "Overall, it was a good experience."
pros: People are nice and there is definitely a life and work balance.
cons: It's a sales dominated organization.

title: "Great place"
pros: Fast paced Always changing Never a dull moment Flexible work schedule
cons: A little too much micro managing Too much red tape that hinders business goals

title: "Sr Consultant"
pros: Great coworkers and department leaders. If your mobile you can move up fast. Very good work/life balance
cons: Compensation is lacking from both pay & benefits.

title: "Finance"
pros: Great people to work with Great work life balance
cons: Slow upward movement Slow change process

title: "Customer Service Representative"
pros: Varied tasks and interesting people to work with. Good training. Opportunities for advancement and educational reimbursement.
cons: Certain job functions were transferred from time to time to other regional service centers leaving the worker to have to move into another position. The company did re-train, but it was hard to give up a job that you knew and loved.

title: "Cares about their employees"
pros: The atmosphere and the other employees are great. They seem to really care about you. They're also great with the community volunteering their time to help out. Free coffee and a lot of room for career growth. They also offer a pension which is fantastic! I don't have to worry about working till I'm 90 years old.
cons: I haven't found any cons yet. Only thing I would like to see is low of a casual wear. We don't see customers so it would be great if we can be more relaxed in attire. Having a gym in the facility would be awesome as well.

title:
"Financial services representative 
Retirement"
pros: -Sponsor you to get your FINRA series 6 -Good benefits. 401k, Health, Pension, Dental, Vision, Discounts on phone, and local places
cons: -Base salary low -Call center -Say they care about metrics and performance data but it really has no effect on advancing -Can't advance unless you know someone and even if you know your stuff you won't advance -Micromanage. If you don't stick extremely close to your schedule you get scolded -Hire more contractors to get through statement period and then don't bring them on as employees -Use the Fortune 100 list to bring in talent, therefore they don't care if you leave because they are constantly getting new applicants

title: "Marketing"
pros: The people are very awesome
cons: Very corporate, slow and bureaucratic.

title: "Manager"
pros: Great culture and diversity and promotes a learning environment of continuous improvement and sustainment.
cons: in San Antonio the advancement opportunities are limited.

title: "Good place to work"
pros: Flexible work place Management seems to care about employees
cons: Pay is average compared to other carriers

title: "Member Care Rep II"
pros: Great Culture, Wonderful Management, Co-workers were also really great, very generous pay. Very strong focus on your development and many opportunities to advance and to explore other roles within the company. Overall a great place to work for many reasons.
cons: Too many supervisor changes. I had 3 different supervisors before leaving. Every time you got situated and comfortable with your team members and your supervisor there would be a shift bid and then you would be assigned to a completely different team. Which also meant moving to a new desk. It started happening too often for me personally.

title: "Senior Analyst, IT Process Mgmt"
pros: Work to life balance is great
cons: Pockets of poor management (rare, however still present)

title: "Sales Support Analyst"
pros: The employees and the relaxed work environment
cons: the pay is a huge con

title: "Management"
pros: I had a very good team to work with
cons: ITD20/20 came in and they removed few roles,this entirely changed the Management view on employees..the SQA manager wanted to safe guard her job so she started pointing out small small mistakes her reportees did and thretended to fire the person. I literally saw a friend of mine go thru that. But luckily my friend got another job and left it was good for him...So what i understood was if your job is in a shake the management will go to any extend to safe guard their job

title: "Automation Engineer"
pros: Great people, and great ideas for group outings
cons: Not many cons but cutting funding in the middle of a project

title: "Claims"
pros: Great co-workers, great pay, decent benefits.
cons: high stress from claim load

title: "Nationwide"
pros: Secure company with good benefits
cons: Need to pay better to start or for people with prior experience.

title: "Great company!"
pros: Great flexibility and great management. The employee benefits and perks are unmatched within this sector. With many schedule perks, flexibility, and potential this company definitely offers plenty of opportunity for a great work/life balance.
cons: The only downside is a call center environment, but each call is a different experience so you get what you put in with each individual customer interactions

title: "Senior management needs a backbone replacement."
pros: Underground parking, decent on site cafe.
cons: Too many impossible projects fall upon the "little guys" for completion, but upper management will not support.

title: "Expected More"
pros: they say they promote work-life balance you can get away with doing nothing and not get fired - if that is what you are looking for they encourage everyone to 'self-manage' - read: you are on your own
cons: difficult to move up - you MUST make alliances with management parking - 5 year wait for FTE's for company garages so you pay $150/month and walk long distances lower than avg pay and increases are 2-3% they move bad associates to other teams rather than addressing bad behaviors health benefits are expensive and not great

title: "Nationwide"
pros: Good pay, benefits are average, could get a good supervisor, work independently
cons: Awful work, stressful, heavy pressure to meet statistics that are very difficult

title: "Work/Life Balance and Benefits"
pros: Nationwide is one of the best companies I have ever worked for where they truly mean what they say when they want their employees to have a work/life balance. The hours and working from home are flexible and leaders are very understanding. Nationwide does care about their associates, and they realize that if their associates are taken care of, their associates will take care of the company.
cons: Compared to other companies in the area, Nationwide has average or lower than average benefits.

title: "If you can stand working the the industry, it's one of the better companies"
pros: Raise/bonus every year, great company culture, they tend to hire good people, and depending on the office there is upward mobility (The Denver office has mobility, the Gainesville office has rarely any).
cons: insurance work can be monotonous and dealing with customers is a pain, lower pay compared to other insurance companies,

title: "Average at best"
pros: Pay was a little above the industry average for call center work
cons: Disorganized, subjective performance reviews, lack of clear vision and a corporate dysfunctional culture

title: "Project Staff positions"
pros: Good benefits and flexible work schedule (depending on department).
cons: Project staffing can be a chaotic position when no one answers to things.

title: "Like every other agency"
pros: Excellent commission, mutual company, flexibility
cons: No base, always changing contracts, hard to plan a long term business

title: "Good jobs with good compensation, little autonomy"
pros: Fair work load, peer learning, tons of relevant training
cons: Micromanagement and politics stunt growth

title: "Very fulfilling"
pros: Great atmosphere great benefits decent pay. I can't say enough about how grateful I am for this opportunity to work here.
cons: You will realize quickly this isn't always a 9-5 job. But if you're willing to put forth the effort, you are rewarded.

title: "Commercial operations"
pros: Used to be a good company to work for.
cons: Commercial operation is in a state of flux. This generates anxiety among department staff.

title: "Inside Injury Claims Adjuster"
pros: -Flexibility -Management encourages development -Fast Paced
cons: None at this time to discuss

title: "Bodily injury adjuster"
pros: Great coworker and benefits
cons: Claim load and pay, work life balance

title: "Good"
pros: Meet lots of people. Pay is pretty good. Professional people. You can work 9 to 5 (although that could hurt you and not get you raises). It all depends what department you find yourself in is what I hear.
cons: Structure is getting overburdened and it can be difficult to relate to management. Competition is getting heavier and heavier. There are getting more and more layoffs.

title: "Great Place to Work!"
pros: Strong brand presence in the community Opportunities for advancement for those who deliver and have strong networking skills
cons: Challenges with rewarding strong performance for those not seeking leadership positions

title: "Sales"
pros: Great benefits and strong commission plan.
cons: Micro management and horrible hours.

title: "Financial Business Specialist"
pros: Pay, benefits, work and life balance, fitness center, close to restaurants and shopping
cons: Downtown traffic is horrible especially during events during the work week. Parking is also horrible during peak events

title: "Nationwide Insurance"
pros: A large company in central Ohio. Well known name recognition. There are a lot of growth opportunities for front line associates.
cons: There is a lack of leadership and overall communication from the VP and Director level. Just get it done attitude.

title: "Agent Representative"
pros: The pros were that it was an easy, laid back job. I enjoyed working in an office setting; friendly environment.
cons: One of the main cons was having to work with irate customers. Especially the ones that won't leave without a fight. The worst.

title: "Associate"
pros: Good Company Brand and recognition
cons: Not a long term career opportunity.

title: "Change fatigue"
pros: Nationwide really cares about their employees, and encourages them to look for and interview for positions they find interesting. It's a great place to grow a career.
cons: They are a big company that is trying to keep up with the constantly changing market place, which means changes in process, organization, etc. while it's good that they want to be nimble, because it's such a large company, the changes take a very long time to implement - which can lead to change fatigue in employees.

title: "Solid, but lackluster"
pros: Worked at company for almost 10 years. Very stable employment. Roughly half of the employees has been at the company for >10 years. Good culture, transparency from executive leadership, lots of opportunity for promotion or internal transfers to further career growth. Offers tons of vacation time that scale with length of tenure.
cons: Almost impossible to get fired or laid off, so a lot of people clock in, sit at their desk, and wait to clock out. It's frustrating to the high-performers. Slow pace of change, lots of bureaucracy. Outdated technology. Compensation seemed to be below average for most roles.

title: "Software QA"
pros: Nothing to mention. Very few - agile, fun.
cons: No work from home. Contractors are discriminated

title: "Great company to work for."
pros: Nationwide is a great company to work for. Open communication and working improvement groups for every employee to make the job easier and better for all. Company truly cares about employees.
cons: Hours worked can be a hassle sometimes, Working in a call center you don't always work 9-5, or M-F. Insurance could be better.

title: "Good place"
pros: The company continues to work to make the company an inviting place for associates. There is more that could be done, but it's better that some. Many I talk to wish they had some of the perks we have.
cons: While they encourage movement between departments, more needs to be done to help facilitate those moves so that they educate and are financially supportive.

title: "Claim Manager"
pros: Good benefits, depending on the team I had the best manager I have ever had. He provided me with autonomy and empowered me to make decisions.
cons: Some other managers I had were very much into micro-management. There was a good-old boys club. They seemed to always be competing as to who worked more and didn't use any of their vacation time each year.

title: "Underwriting Intern"
pros: The company is very family oriented and flexible. The training is unbeatable making the experience fun and easy to catch on to.
cons: It is a very large company with a typical corporate America structure, which may not be for all people.

title: "Great company to work for"
pros: - Pay is good compared to the market - Great work environment and benefits - Work/Life balance is great - Flexible work schedules - Management listens to employee concerns
cons: - Top heavy - Need to talk your way up, hard work does not get you promoted

title: "Great!"
pros: It was a great experience and learning opportunity. The culture is amazing!
cons: There was no cons working at Nationwide

title: "Business Process Engineer"
pros: Progressive Leadership in retirement planning
cons: Contractors in some areas are not treated like employees

title: "Good company!"
pros: Flexible work schedules and lots of room to grow.
cons: Benefits could be better than what they give us

title: "Customer service"
pros: Great team, atmosphere, opportunity for advancement and great people
cons: Couldnt say there were any cons

title: "Claims Represenative"
pros: Working with great managment team.
cons: Downside was working very late shift.

title: "OK"
pros: They have their moments of greatness when the management listens to their employees and agents, but most the time they do not listen.
cons: The management have become a group of "yes" people just protecting their jobs and trying not to get fired. Their computer systems are poor and need to be updated.

title: "Nearly 20 years of good work, friends and pay"
pros: Almost all the people I worked with were top shelf. I left with more good friends than I had when I arrived,nd even now that I have left I retain many friends.
cons: The annual performance reviews are meaningless.

title: "Sr. Team Lead"
pros: Full benefits including a Pension, Tuition Reimbursement, Adoption Reimbursement, 38.75 hour work week, clear career path, lateral career options, relocation packages, full size gym, etc
cons: Pay seems to be a little lower than industry average

title: "Internship Experience"
pros: Easy to clear interview. Very good team. Lot to learn.
cons: Lot of False promises from Managers.

title: "Great opportunities"
pros: Great opportunities for professional development and work/life balance
cons: Group think, silos (large, complex company with specialized functions), can become typecast

title: "Okay department"
pros: Good employees, advancement potential. Good experience for those looking for a career in underwriting.
cons: Management really doesn't know what it's doing. Appears to be transforming into a call center

title: "Developer"
pros: The best office culture you will find - Everyone is a joy to work with, and the approach to work is merit based and very laid back. I've never had an interpersonal problem and team members are always a joy to work with. Additionally, there is a lot of room to step up to the plate if you're a motivated employee. Management is always keeping an eye out for those who like to take on more responsibility.
cons: Job roles can sometimes be less defined than you would like. Compensation is lower than you might get on the coasts.

title: "Nationwide Richmond"
pros: Good people, benefits are ok
cons: Favoritism, Promotions not based on performance/sometimes the only way to get promoted is to try to leave, low pay

title: "Excellent place to work!"
pros: -Excellent management. Organized into teams with a manager for each. Each department has one associate director that answers to the director of the building. -Work/life balance is great. In my department, you work an 8:00-4:15, Monday-Friday schedule. We have to work one holiday per year, which is rewarded with an extra day off. -Workload is generally high, however it is usually low stress and you have plenty of time to complete your tasks. -You are rewarded and you receive praise when management receives a positive survey, customer review, etc. -Education assistance, maternal/paternal leave, family time (free time off for emergencies), lots of "grown up" perks
cons: Cubicle work environment, people occasionally get on each other's nerves working in close proximity to each other.

title: "Manager of Applications"
pros: Nationwide is good to dedicated associates
cons: Limited leader opportunity outside of Columbus, OH and Des Moines, IA

title: "Great place, family oriented"
pros: Friendly work environment with great management.
cons: Needs better training, more motivation for employees

title: "Flexible Environment & Nationwide Nice"
pros: You can really make your work schedule be whatever you need it to be which is fantastic. They truly do value a work life balance and they will work with you to achieve it.
cons: Nationwide nice is a concept that everyone is nice and doesn't want to rock the boat, to your face. Once you are gone, that is a different story. Nationwide moves management around too much so you feel like you never get to settle in with one manager.

title: "Consultant"
pros: Nationwide has a very diverse working environment.
cons: I haven't experienced anything negative since I've been here.

title: "used to be better"
pros: good people, strong business model
cons: too much process, inefficient, hard to execute and get things done

title: "Run away"
pros: They pay you but it's never enough
cons: Too many buildings 70s furniture for some while others get new things. Favoritism is rampant. If you don't fall in with the cool kids be prepared to be harassed

title: "Claims Specialist III"
pros: Good flexibility and chance to move up to a certain degree. Great opportunities to move within the company.
cons: Often understaffed in claims, getting more claims than Claim audits were designed around. Claims does not have the telecommute flexiabilties as other departments.

title: "Triage Specialist - Production Support"
pros: -Competitive pay -Underground parking -Decent facility -Growing company -CEO -Nice location in Scottsdale -Average vacation time -Everyone gets a company laptop
cons: -Micromanaging at all levels, even from the Consultants who aren't managers -This position is the dumping grounds for tasks that nobody else wants to do even if it doesn't fall within your job description -High school mentality - If you don't agree with the people on your team, prepared to be an outcast and talked about behind your back -Condescending coworkers who act like know-it-alls -If you don't work nights and weekends you're not considered a team player -Team abuses telecommute privilege resulting in little presence in the office. This has created a bad reputation for the department from the CEO and upper management -Manager doesn't know how to do the work so only listens to the Consultants on the team, even if the Specialists are correct or have better ideas -Non-constructive criticism from management/coworkers. Everyone wants to make themselves look good by blaming others -Mediocre rating/issuance systems -Poor bonuses -401k takes 5 years until you're vested

title: "Awesome place to work"
pros: One of the top places to work. Opportunities are abundant, great family like work environment.
cons: Like any place else, you have to know what you want to accomplish in your career to grow within Nationwide.

title: "Csr"
pros: Sitting Training Big company name Cafe Security Some trainers are very fun
cons: Training techniques arent hands on Favoritism Not monday to Friday like training

title: "woring in agents office"
pros: good products to sell, assisting policyholders with their insurance needs
cons: working in agent office offers no benefits such as retirement or insurance

title: "Claims Specialist"
pros: Interesting work. Lots to learn. Stability. Excellent benefits.
cons: Political drama in the office. Opportunities for growth are limited unless you are mobile.

title: "Good"
pros: Culture is nice. Potential to move up and grow is available with hard work and dedication. Hard work is noticed by senior management.
cons: Lack of communication can be concerining

title: "IT Ops Manager"
pros: Well there is not much to say good about this company
cons: Too much old boys and old girls club at Nationwide.

title: "MD Field claims rep."
pros: Plenty of training opportunities provided.
cons: Work load snowballs out of control. No time for training.

title: "Like it okay"
pros: awesome training program. lots of help and motivation on the floor. loved the environment and teammates
cons: Sometimes the workload was a lot. lots of rules to remember which is understandable since its insurance and there are laws and regulations which apply

title: "Pretty Good"
pros: Great staff and learning experience. Educated team willing to help.
cons: I have none thus far.

title: "Director"
pros: Good culture, too nice.Cares for people
cons: Leadership is changing. Average benefits and pay

title: "Great company to work for."
pros: Great inclusive culture. Great on-site amenities: fitness center, cafeteria, game rooms, on-site nurse. Clean, beautiful call center. Management actually seems like they care about every employee.
cons: Long training for some departments (however, some departments require a lot of information)

title: "A great experience overall but in the end became a real challenge."
pros: Solid benefits and decent pay. Opportunities to learn and grow. Other amenities like cafeteria and fitness center. Good work-life balance.
cons: Like any large company politics can be challenging- almost like extended High School in its viciousness. Easy to suddenly land with a bad leader. Bureaucracy can be suffocating.

title: "Receptionist and Social Media Specialist"
pros: Family oriented, great job to have while in school, normal business hours, compassionate co-workers, and the owner truly cares about her employees.
cons: The work can be monotonous and people will undermine your intelligence. As a receptionist, you'll be expected to take out the trash, which isn't the most glamorous thing to do. Lots of paper waste. Not the most environmentally friendly.

title: "High stress job"
pros: Pay is pretty good and the benefits are many to choose from. Just depends on what level of benefits you can personally afford.
cons: Stressful, deadlines, somewhat unfriendly except for select people. Not much empathy for family needs or getting to go to medical appointments.

title: "Executive Assistant"
pros: Great online training available to employees.
cons: Salary is not competitive based on market average. Organization is in constant upheaval with regard to restructuring and reorganization. Company's expense management policies are the equivalent of "stepping over dollars to get to pennies." Too many levels of red tape involved company-wide when trying to accomplish even the simplest tasks.

title: "Avo"
pros: Location, benefits, pension, bonuses, diversity are all better than most in the greater central Ohio area. Community involvement is also very high
cons: Too much passive aggressive from leadership. Too much red tape to get things done most of the time making things harder than it needs to be

title: "CSR/Agent"
pros: Close to home, Liked product
cons: Not a good professional environment

title: "Not all its cracked up to be"
pros: No nights no weekends salary plus commission major holidays days off
cons: Hard to constantly make sales and try to save customers money when the rates aren't the best constantly making a changes and the agents are the last to know hard to advance.

title: "Attorney - OCLO"
pros: Flexible work environment; ability to move between departments and develop / grow in career
cons: The company is going through nearly constant and ongoing reorganizations. The hiring of the new general counsel has increased the political pressures within the office. It is very easy to get crosswise with the wrong person unintentionally and your career / opportunities within the legal department end. The culture is very passive aggressive. You have to watch your back constantly. Your ability to succeed is largely based on the political strength of your management team. There are generally too many chiefs and those how are actually doing the work are treated poorly.

title: "Agent"
pros: There are no pros with this company any more.
cons: Changes direction at the drop of a hat. Complete lack of focus.

title: "Good place to work"
pros: Good benefits, great people. Loved that there was a gym on site. Good training. Good flexibility. Lots of opportunities. Lots of teamwork.
cons: A bit on the boring side, but not too bad. It gets old sitting in a cubicle. Wish there were better desks and a place to put your coat or a spare pair of shoes.

title: "Just OK"
pros: large brand, decent benefits, avg pay
cons: not fair on promotions and employee growth

title: "Insurance Agent"
pros: smaller family style office, fast paced friendly environment
cons: being a smaller agency not much room for growth

title: "Nationwide"
pros: Big company. Good people to work with. Stable. Benefits are pretty good. 401K. Offers different areas of the Company to explore and build your knowledge base.
cons: Career Growth within certain departments

title: "CSU claim processor"
pros: Keying all day with minimal phone time. Easy if you can type fast and have critical thinking. Extra money if you work holidays.
cons: Training program doesn't cover near enough of the situations you will face. Software is frustrating to operate because only the seasoned veterans know how to use it, but they don't write the training or quality expectations. Health insurance makes you waste your time to make it more affordable.

title: "Mcr"
pros: Days off, chill atmosphere, huge cafeteria, you can schedule your breaks whenever you want, pay is pretty good starting off.
cons: It's a big work atmosphere, on the phone all day, a lot of gay people, I really think they hire anyone that's gay on purpose for diversity, if people aren't gay they look weird. It feels like Austin, TX. In there. The company increases rates all the time without letting customers know and leave the workers to explain why their insurance increased and Nationwide hasn't given us a proper explanation on why increases happen. I Mt seems pretty shady.

title: "Trainer"
pros: Company has good values, provide good benefits for long term employees, makes time for fun
cons: Pay for certain positions much lower than national averages. The lower on the ladder you are, the worse it is

title: "Good Company That May be Headed in Wrong Direction"
pros: Good work/life balance, mostly transparent, values engagement of employees, co- workers are professional and courteous, good benefits, creates good open door policy culture that encourages feedback to management.
cons: Becoming too Corporate culture centric, pay lower then other companies, too much reorganization of staff happening, needs to allow time for change impact to happen instead of constantly changing.

title: "Underwriting"
pros: Large and stable coming any.
cons: Many silos and a very political culture.

title: "Do not work in Call Center or Processing."
pros: You meet great people in the call center and other areas in the building. You can dress down daily.
cons: Low compensation for what the extremely stressful job requires. You work with on systems that are outdated and not customer friendly. You are on the phones with extremely unhappy customers that yell, belittle, and/or curse at you ALL Day long because their policy canceled. Customers can't pay their bills but want their car insurance active right now. When a caller wants you to escalate calls to "supervisors", you get push back and are expected to continue to take the abuse of the customer. Your escalated call is refused. Management is untrustworthy, unprofessional, and caddy. VP down to Leads. Trust me, they will smile at you to your face then talk horribly behind your back. Walk by an office or desk!! You can catch these conversations daily. Just hope it's not about you! Upper management has successfully fired, demoted, or drove out some awesome managers/supervisors that really cared about their teams in the last 2 years. If you choose to go on an interview, ask about the management turnover! 10 + managers/supervisors is what I counted just off the top of my head in the last two years. No, they weren't promoted either. That tells you alot when you are in a very small call center.

cons: Everybody seems to be Ohio State fans.

title: "Amazing Opportunities, Nice People, Don't Squander It!"
pros: The company is large, obviously, and profitable. Everyone in town has immense respect for the brand and it feels like you're part of something. Lots of respect for family and duties at home, at least that's what I experienced. If you're in the right area, you can achieve a very high level of pay.
cons: They don't always like it when you achieve very high levels of pay (commissions my team earned internally on wholesale activity) I was there during a time of upheaval so I really can't judge, it was a tough time for all involved. Definitely a BIG company with politics and lots of keeping everyone happy, but again it was a time of reorganization. I hear it has gotten alot better and everyone I talk to is pretty happy to work there! Just be ready to put on a good face and work for the good of the firm. It's common sense. Don't take things personally or get cocky to try and stand out, they respect a passionate team player who puts his head down and does the work. Voice your ideas but don't expect them to be adopted quickly, or at all. Just do your best and don't squander the opportunity.

title: "Good, but you can do much better"
pros: -NW is an institution of Columbus. By being a part of it you will deal with other large financial companies across the country and the exposure and experience gained in that regard is good, along with the NW brand on your resume. -Access to Blue Jackets, The Memorial Tournament, other special events in Columbus. -Great balance of work/play. You don't sweat the job after you clock out everyday and generally vacation time is adequate. -Coworkers generally are very pleasant and amiable.
cons: -From my time here at least, it seemed as if this was a place a ton of people chose to work at just for a paycheck, which of course is something everyone needs to survive at the end of the day, but other people look for more purpose and fulfilling ways to spend their time. The rest of the people just work here their entire lives with no dreams of doing anything besides being a manager for their department. -While people obviously people want to move up the ladder and succeed at their jobs, with a lot of the employees, there just seems to be a pervading sense of "I don't really care about this", so they end up burned out by the job and pursue something elsewhere more aligned with their true interests. As a result you tend to find a bottleneck effect within most employees-either pretty fresh out of college or they have been here for a long time (10+ years) -If your position requires you to take inbound calls, prepare for the stress of that, you will get plenty from obnoxious/demanding agents and coworkers higher up the ladder than you demanding you take care of THEIR business before everyone else's. -Bureaucratic nature makes it difficult for your voice to truly be heard sometimes.

title: "Stability... Always Most Valued in Hindsight"
pros: I got my post-college start at a subsidiary of Nationwide and then spent years working directly for the company. Nearly four and a half years after leaving, I have the perspective to appreciate how lucky I was. The company treated me very fairly, and its culture was patient, meritocratic and supportive. I was always adequately or well compensated, and there was plenty of opportunity. I was always given training and support to accomplish my work. I have grown to appreciate this access much more after working for other companies that are less generous with these essentials. Nationwide was also a relatively stable environment. Although there was significant change and reorganization during my time there, employees were seldom laid off when a job classification obsoleted. In fact, most that I knew were given months of advance warning that their position was being eliminated, and encouraged to apply for other positions internally. This was consistent with Nationwide's general culture of developing talent within the company and encouraging lateral job moves as part of career paths. Again, I have come to appreciate this tendency far more after realizing how rare that approach is. Stories of the executives who started in entry-level positions and gained expertise over time were common knowledge, sometimes celebrated by the subject of the stories themselves. Management culture was generally forthright and friendly, and willing to coach employees for performance improvement rather than simply terminate them. As a new employee I made plenty of mistakes, including misunderstanding office etiquette, and am continually grateful to the managers and mentors who took the time to teach me. Overall, I found Nationwide a very professional environment, and a great place to grow for those who are interested in an earnest, reliable organization.
cons: Admittedly, property and casualty insurance is not the sexiest field. So those looking for excitement or hip coworkers may not be as happy with the culture. Nationwide has had plenty of organizational growing pains, especially in its IT area. Sometimes it was clear that executive level strategic vision was regarded as unrealistic by middle management, which led to mixed success or long delays for some initiatives. Employees in my area frequently felt disconnected from the strategic level considerations discussed at all company, or division wide meetings. Although this a fairly meritocratic organization, every company has politics. This is probably more of a concern for those hoping to get into upper management or executive jobs. It was not uncommon to see some of these leaders leave with obvious frustrations at leadership or their inability to effect change.

title: "Nationwide Financial Director"
pros: Benefits are good, company still has a Pension, relaxed dress at times
cons: If you have an a&&hole for a manager, you will never be happy. Too much gossip. Too much emphasis on engagement and managing "their" way, regardless of whether its the right way. At times, management cares more about the outcome than how they get to it, trampling on people and members to get there. Work life balance is non-existent at times.

title: "commercial collection manager Sec for LTD fordwarding desk"
pros: in business over 35 years

title: "Decent pay, Harrisburg office doesn't care for associates"
pros: Good pay, lots of outside activity, volunteer programs. Ohio office is the best to work with in training programs, good training programs
cons: Management, they just hire based on who knows who and not the experience the person has. Leaders can fail a whole team. Health benefits could be better

title: "Director"
pros: Ability to move across departments and build your skills and experience. Great work like balance in most departments.
cons: Not publicly traded and seems to allow for leadership with limited street value to maintain position longer than other companies I've worked for.

title: "Financial Analyst Review"
pros: Great people, large company, lots of opportunity
cons: Can be difficult to move to a separate area of business than you began in within the company

title: "New-ish Nationwider"
pros: The work-life balance is incredible. Managers are incredibly understanding when it comes to taking time for yourself. The benefits are also fantastic, and I feel my skills and knowledge are highly valued by my peers, partners, and superiors.
cons: The ebb and flow of the work still varies a lot (going from very slow to very busy), and some of the work/revisions can be overly prescriptive.

title: "Senior Consultant"
pros: Nationwide's culture promotes a work family atmosphere welcoming grass roots participation and promoting equal pay with its company values. Now retired after almost 40 years of service I did witness management changing from no women to a much better mix of women, ethnic diversity, race diversity among management.
cons: Similar to most company the execution of company policies and values can vary widely between bosses and departments. If you are unfortunately to have a difficult boss who circumvents polices of fairness it is very difficult to voice the truth. HR is not in a position to be the associate advocate.

title: "Claims Adjuster"
pros: Great coworkers, competitive salary, opportunity to move to different roles in the company, work campus in downtown Des Moines is great, positive culture,
cons: I've worked in a couple different departments within the Claims organization and it feels out of control. Executive level is unable or unwilling to get a handle on staffing and workload, and prefers to have low level management try to motivate employees to handle the work of 2-3 people. Work-life balance is terrible, and it's bad for employees and customers. Departments within Nationwide seem barely able to communicate or work together in a meaningful way.

title: "Great Place to work"
pros: Great work environment. Management genuinely care about you and want you to move up. Easy work and offers plenty of training and opportunities to do better.
cons: Work can be mundane sometimes. And also repetitive. Desk job, so you will have to stay active. Easy to gain weight

title: "Sr. Sales and Service Advocate"
pros: Nationwide stays very active and involved in the community. They also have an excellent training and operations team.
cons: Communication from regional leadership teams seems to be an issue. Recent region alignment and distribution channels have many current associates on edge.

title: "Great job"
pros: benefits, advancement opportunities, hours, coworkers, pay

title: "Well intentions.  Passive aggressive"

title: "This company is my home!"
pros: I have been rehired by Nationwide and I can say that people here care about people! If you've ever left and come back, you will see the grass isn't greener elsewhere. There's lots of reasons we are in the Top 100 companies to work for in the US. Supportive peers and leadership are an example. Be thankful for what we have in terms of benefits and pay at Nationwide!
cons: The only downside is that we are a large company which can make processes move a little slower at times, but that also helps us to make sure the right people have made the right decisions. Some people who have worked here 20+ years don't see how great they really have it in this company and sometimes I think they take it for granted!

title: "Great Company"
pros: Great benefits, great time off, work-life balance is great.
cons: Pay may be lower than competitors

title: "Director"
pros: Large employer with lots of opportunity especially for college grads and entry or mid management. Competitive pay in some areas and positions. Great written values and potential for a great culture. Charity and volunteer work engagement. Lots of learning and development resources. Come across great people.
cons: Good ol' boy club is strong in the leadership ranks. Friends of leaders get promotions. Too many chiefs not enough Indians. Very political as you begin to promote up. Managing your brand/reputation and seeking mentorships with "the right people" is all you can really do to help yourself. The basic calendar of a home office leader will have a disproportionate amount of meetings focused on political matters and CYA matters rather than working on items needing their attention. You either drink the cool-aid or you are an outsider so be ready to "play the game." Large company thus implementing change is very difficult especially when leadership at different levels can't embrace (generally the long tenured ones) it or are too slow to. Too many CYA activities monopolize time. Work life balance for leadership becomes an issue the higher you go up. In a nut shell, uninformed decisions made by leaders who hide in their offices and then time spent by directors (sometime AVPs) reacting to those decisions and cleaning up the mess made. And if you don't effectively clean up and fix it, you will have performance issues yourself. Extreme break down in accountability and the worst of all anti-core values behavior by officers to whom you should be looking up to... not down on. There are many amazing leaders but the bad ones ruin it. So as you can imagine basic symptoms flair up: turnover, sick leave/stress leave, performance issues, lack of engagement, interdepartmental transfers, poor quality work outcomes, etc. The passing of the old guard will eventually take place but we have LOTS of damage to manage until then. Very territorial as business areas are fighting/competing for staffing dollars and resources thus building adversarial relationships and poor behavior of those working in that environment. CEO - saw him on videos but do not know much about him as a person, what he is all about, his leadership, goals, passions, etc.

title: "Nice company for staying until retirement"

cons: The company is very cozy for the senior group. Employees are relatively age. There are few opportunities for young generation and ambitious contractors.

When you're first hired, you do not get normal schedule, you have to earn normal schedule by being top 20% then they become available

title: "Paralegal"
pros: I can only speak about my short-term experience working in the company's legal department. The benefits and salary are very competitive to above average. The company emphasizes a work/life balance. Managing attorney was very professional and refreshingly warm and friendly. She was always available to answer questions, was very supportive, and had a positive attitude. I honestly believe she genuinely cared about the employees.
cons: The company's proprietary litigation software is a nightmare. Nationwide's horribly slow network makes file maintenance and case management almost impossible, especially since the caseload is enormous. IT tries to be helpful but can only do so much when the system is not modern enough to handle the internet traffic into Ohio (Nationwide's headquarters). It is also confusing, user-unfriendly, and complex interface. The department was grossly understaffed and if someone was out sick or on vacation, we were expected to work on that person's caseload as well. The target productivity expectations are completely unattainable. I received literally hundreds of emails a day. In my opinion, I wasn't able to spend an ample amount of time on projects to double check my work. Updating the software system to input the case status took almost as much time as the project itself! Supervisors required us to file Motions to Compel for late discovery from plaintiffs despite the fact our own discovery was also overdue at the time. Overtime was completely prohibited. Employees were closely watched to make sure nobody clocked in/out a minute earlier or later than one's set time schedule, including lunch. There was no litigation support to help with copies, mail, or typical runner's duties. Paralegals do not go to trial with their attorneys. When I walked in my first day of work my desk was piled high with files and papers, the status of which nobody knew. I wish I had left then and there. We were required to attend numerous weekly phone conferences consuming valuable time that could be spent on our caseloads. While management asked for feedback and encouraged questions, staff was under the belief that any input was futile, therefore, questions or comments were generally suppressed. The phone conferences amounted to cheerleading sessions that were repetitive, redundant, and a colossol waste of time for those of us working in the legal department. They discussed company profits, etc. that may have been important to very upper management, marketing, or sales, but certainly not the legal department employees. Consequently, these phone conferences were just another stumbling block in my efforts to reach unattainable goals.

title: "Marketing"
pros: Very stable, Fortune 100 company. One of the few companies out there that matches 401K at 6% AND provides a pension. Lots of benefits and is caring about their employees.
cons: Nationwide doesn't change fast. Sr Leaders decide change is needed and with 35K employees the company takes years to transition. And by the time we are moving down that path leadership has changed so the direction changes too.

Nationwide offers the following: Flexibility Great Team Environment Good Pay Many Career Growth/Progression Opportunities Accrued Time-off "Take care of their own" Tuition reimbursement

title: "Create your own opportunities"
pros: This is a very large Fortune 100 company that prides themselves on culture and how they treat their associates & customers. There are a lot of genuinely good people that work here that want to help you succeed. The pay is about average, but considering the benefits (including a pension) it's not that bad. At the end of the day, your path is up to you. There are so many opportunities to move around departments and/or the country. Just be advised that you will find more opportunities in Columbus, OH or Des Moines, IA where the corporate offices are located. If you're good at networking and not afraid to ask questions, there are really no limits on what you can achieve. Plenty of people are willing to mentor. With that being said, it's up to you and you alone to define what you want and then go and get it.
cons: If you're not in Columbus, opportunities and resources can be extremely limited. A bad performance review can diminish your opportunities for advancement. You oftentimes get notes from management that seem to be focused on perception rather than results or efficiency. Be mindful of politics, but that's to be expected at a corporation of this size. Also, the archaic IT systems can prevent one from being competitive in the modern workforce. I believe the IT infrastructure is so large and complex that it's too difficult and expensive to keep up with the times. I have used software from the 1980s that really shouldn't exist anymore. The medical plan is one of the worst plans I've ever seen. You pay a high premium AND high deductible. They tried to justify it by referencing the changes in healthcare legislation. Nationwide's medical plan is not good at all compared to other companies who offer generous employer sponsored medical plans.

title: "Love it!"

cons: It can be overwhelming at times, moving up to a higher position doesn't have a higher wage.

title: "Good and Bad"
pros: Decent pay, good benefits, a few good managers.
cons: Zero work life balance, expected to work nights and weekends just to keep up. Let's be honest, claims is not glamorous but it's seriously a grind at Nationwide. Staffing is terrible, constantly understaffed which makes life miserable for reps. The quality intents, the metrics the file auditors use to score performance, are ridiculous. There is no way for the average rep to meet them. In order to hit the highest score to get the max raise, your files have to be pretty much perfect. And if you're unlucky enough to have a manager that doesn't like you, you're screwed no matter how great your files are. Depending on where you are, promotion opportunities can be ok or non-existent. Also highly dependent on whether your manager or director like you. I would not recommend and I'm glad I got out when I did.

title: "Actuarial"

cons: Salary is low compared to industry. There is a tendency to fill higher up positions with external hires instead of promoting from within, so difficult to move up

title: "Proud to be a part of this company"

title: "Looking for another job"

title: "I like it"
pros: Pay, benefits, and company culture. They pay pretty well and have great incentives to work more productively. Most of their benefits are pretty good (except health care - read the cons), so many people stay with the company because of just that. Folks are pretty friendly there too. Bosses encourage employees to share ideas that make our work more productive while beneficial to the company and customers.
cons: Attendance policy. They'll write you up if you don't give a 3-week advance notice that you'll be absent (they call them "occurences"). You earn your days off as you work and it all goes into one little bank called My Time. If you're sick, they the days from My Time (not like most jobs with the traditional sick days). Since most people wouldn't know whether or not they're going to be sick 3 weeks in advance, you'll more than likely be at risk of getting an occurrence unless, of course, you can prove that you were sick. Unlike most jobs where a simple doctor's note will suffice, Nationwide requires that you file an FMLA claim through a 3rd party vendor they use. Since the paperwork has to be filled out by a doctor, you have to get a physician fill out a ton of paperwork every time you are out sick, including colds, flus, and other illnesses you could normally treat at home. Since Nationwide's health care benefits all require some kind of deductible, you'll more than likely be paying a doctor a load of cash to help you not get an write-up.

title: "Nationwide is on their (and sometimes your) side."
pros: Nationwide is an enormous organization, meaning that there are a wide variety of opportunities at their large-campus locations. A tremendous amount of effort is expended to maintain a positive company image as well as foster enthusiasm in their ranks. Wages are great, 401(k) contribution is good, and, unlike many companies, there is also a pension program.
cons: There's nothing wrong with an organization speaking highly of their own successes, values, etc., but this company seems almost a little bit too in love with itself, which can lead to arrogance in decision-making and an immunity to constructive feedback. Meetings with upper leadership quickly devolve into un-constructive "kiss-up" sessions. This is fine for the most part: a large national carrier like Nationwide, Geico, States All- & Farm, etc. can make money hand over fist in direct sales while running on auto pilot as quantity beats quality. This breezy attitude, unfortunately, does not fly in the independent agent market that Nationwide is attempting to infiltrate (in part, by purchasing regional carriers- which is how I became a NW employee). All the witty TV commercials and treacly appeals to company values mean nothing to agents when service suffers due to closing offices and the resulting attrition of staff and talent. Additionally, going back to the "Pro" about compensation, if you have health problems, expect the "great" wages to be spent on out-of-pocket medical expenses as NW, probably like many companies now, only offer what is essentially the bare-minimal product that can legally be called "health insurance".
