title: "Medical Payments Adjuster"
pros: Management encourages growth and movement within the company.
cons: Workload can be unmanageable at times.

title: "Specialist, process management"
pros: The culture is engaging and all encompassing. They take great pride in community involvement and work life balance.
cons: Advancement potential is a struggle. Being the best at what you do doesn't get you further ahead-just gets you more work.

title: "Decent place to work"
pros: benefits are nice and the pay is decent. management is very helpful
cons: not a lot of communication between departments and various other locations, outdated software

title: "I feel appreciated"
pros: welcoming environment. Managers are willing to help you succeed you'll be on the phones and all of a sudden people will be bringing you chick fil le or popsicles or one morning you'll go to your desk and there will be a some star bursts with a note that says WE APPRECIATE YOU! there is also overtime available when ever you want to do it
cons: no cons there really isnt much worth complaining about

title: "Associate Agent"
pros: Agency is small and the Agent Owner and coworker get along well and work together.
cons: No promotions or chance to grow.

title: "Wonderful People"
pros: Lots of opportunity for advancement in the area of claims especially..
cons: Lots of long meetings in my opinion..

title: "Great company, out-of-touch upper management. Crushing workload in the Denver office."
pros: Collaborative environment. Depending on direct manager can be a good day-to-day work environment. Lots of young, talented, professional coworkers. Starting pay is decent (after training period and promotion to "salary" - which comes around 6-8 months), good benefits, flex time. Modern new office. Fortune 100 company with excellent brand recognition and (for the most part) a solid reputation within the industry and with the general public (be prepared to hear that damn jingle every time you mention where you work).
cons: Some direct managers micromanage associates. There are constantly increasing demands on the performance metrics of associates and support staff with increasing workload and NO increase in pay. No overtime, no incentives, nada. Mid-to-upper management is deeply out of touch with the day-to-day workload and struggles of the associates who keep the company afloat. Culture is turning toxic as a result. Management insists claims dept is "fully staffed" when the workload is unmanageable (nearly double what it was a year ago). Promoting to a new department from the entry level position is effectively a pay cut. The base pay is slightly more, but other departments (for the most part) do not have the option of working alternative shifts ( which comes with a 10% pay differential) that almost all entry level associates are required to work.

title: "Adjuster"
pros: Good hours,covered parking, clear expectations
cons: Far away from West valley

title: "It was the best of times, it was the worst of times..."
pros: Depending on your department there can be good opportunities for advancement. The culture is a little more relaxed compared to other similar companies.
cons: So much of your experience depends on your supervisor. HR tends to not listen to the employee only the manager during a dispute which as a 10+ year employee with no previous issues that was very disappointing. Benefits have gotten more expensive and not as good. People are often forced into supporting initiatives they don't like with fear of not being a "team player" if they express concerns.

title: "Steady work environment with no opportunity for advancement."
pros: Great benefits package for insurance, also offering pension which is rare these days.
cons: No room for advancement, deception about job moving out of state, established circles that are hard to get in.

title: "MLRP Management Associate"
pros: Awesome exposure to senior leadership Great Opportunities
cons: No Cons that I can think of

title: "Licensed Sales and Service Representative"
pros: Nationally recognized brand which helps in prospecting which more than often translates into greater sales.
cons: Irregular hours, minimal base salary.

title: "internal"
pros: Stable company . Good benefits and 401k
cons: very political. not easy to be promoted

title: "Specialist, Project Manager"
pros: Work life balance, growth opportunities, culture and people. Working from home is no problem, taking time off is very easy and management is very warm
cons: Salary is slightly below average, difficult for Internationals to get green card sponsorship, environment is slightly political and its important to know the right people

title: "Great group of people"
pros: great flexibility with job responsibility. fantastic group of people to work with as well. lots of opportunities to learn and grow
cons: isolated work group can make getting voice heard across the company tough. small department can lead to the same issues

title: "Great company going through transition"
pros: Company with a national presence, multitude of areas and disciplines to work in, great relocation assistance, offers a pension plan, mutual company.
cons: Like most Fortune 100 companies it's filled with much office/corporate politics, going through tremendous internal change from personnel changes to a complete system overhaul. Lack of accountability within certain departments. Can be challenging to get promoted if you're not connected to the right people. Lack of diversity and focus on emerging markets. It's a Midwest company.

title: "Sr. Business Analyst in retirement plans"
pros: Nationwide is a large company so there is a lot of room for growth
cons: Retirement plans under internal sales and service does not live the Nationwide values. The atmosphere is really negative and the management in retirement plans is petty.

title: "Contractor"
pros: Located Downtown Columbus, good coworkers
cons: handling a lot of phone calls anywhere from 40 which is a slow day to 100 during busy months, difficult customers. Call centers can be stressful

title: "CL Processor II"
pros: Training for your current position is typically available, but there aren't many pros.
cons: No growth, poor communication, and overly social/caddy leadership. I am a known "favorite" of my boss but by no means does it mean that I agree with it. The office is like high school. It's a social gathering and if you don't git in, you are judged and treated differently. It's sad.

title: "Underwriting"
pros: Excellent benefits, Fortune 100 company
cons: Not too many opportunities to make career changes within the company

title: "Administrative Assistant"
pros: Great co-workers. Good chances of on line training. Good support system among peers.
cons: Benefits were lacking. Management was not transparent when office was closing. Personnel was indifferent to needs as a result of closing.

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Upward mobility, flexibility, collaborative culture
cons: Downsizing locations from 27 to 6-10 core locations

title: "Good internship"
pros: Agile teamspace and great culture. A professional environment but one that is welcoming.
cons: I worked in IT and it is truly IT for a big company. Not many development opportunities but that is to be expected.

title: "Underwriting assistant"
pros: Good perks, good flexibility
cons: Gossip city 101. Management stinks

title: "bad company to work for"
pros: nice location and nice place to eat close by
cons: bad culture, no management support and direction

title: "Great culture"
pros: Mutual company that invests in its members, associates and community.
cons: Depending on the area you work in as well as your manager, your experience can be different

title: "Executive Assistant"
pros: Great opportunity to network. Comp package is good. Education reimbursement is a wonderful added value.
cons: Advancement opportunities for Exempt associates are Very Limited. Although education opportunities are encouraged, advancing your career within Nationwide to a Non-Exempt position is Very Unlikely..

title: "Good company. Everybody contributing no power games"
pros: Care about employees , no micro managing lots of projects and opportunities, goal is get job done no playing ego or power games everybody are contributing. Value opinion
cons: More documentation , instead of have to ask around for information .

title: "Personal Lines Underwriter"
pros: Over the time I've been employed as an underwriter for Nationwide, I've had several great managers there. Almost everyone is trying to do the right thing for our customers.
cons: Like most jobs in almost any industry and any job or career, the company wants you to work your fair share and answer as many calls as possible.

title: "Architect"
pros: Good Company , Great Benefits, Good Management
cons: Big Company, Know little about the company strategy

title: "Great company when you're in the right business unit"
pros: -Pension -Internal job postings are frequent -Generally, people really care about their work -Odds are you'll be on a high-performing team -Flexibility, including work from home (can depend on your manager's attitude about this, though) -Missing the inclusion part of "diversity and inclusion"
cons: -Engagement results not believable -Healthcare coverage not that great -Moving in and out of jobs is EXTREMELY political -Too many bad leaders are allowed to stay in their roles -Some areas the culture can be too much like "be like us" because there's a high focus on fitting in and being liked -Pay raises barely keep with inflation/cost of living

title: "Claims"
pros: Beautiful campus. Nice part of scottsdale. Lots of people retiring so opportunities are growing. Underground parking is nice in the summer.
cons: Nationwide is the parent company and is gobbling up any remaining local culture. Office politics and grudges can stall your career for years.

title: "Great company to work with"
pros: Great benefits. This company will continue to educate yourself while working. Work and home life stability is important to them.
cons: Must have license before you are able to work with company BUT they will pay for the course

title: "It's a good place to work."
pros: The benefits are good and there are a lot of resources available there. It's big and has a good social element.
cons: You have to write your own performance review twice a year. It's cubicle life. It's easy to get lost in the crowd.

title: "Nationwide App Developer"
pros: Great benefits, good work environment
cons: Not a lot of upward mobility for developers, not great compensation

title: "Level One Adjuster"
pros: Wonderful department managers at the time - company does care about their policyholders and doing what is right.
cons: Heavy work load- long hours

title: "Mixed feelings"
pros: Lots of training involved
cons: changed directions of the company mid-year

title: "Material Damage Field Claims Associate"
pros: Ability to work from home
cons: Understaffed which affects work-life balance

title: "Brokerage claims"
pros: Flexible work schedule. Good pay to get you in, then zero to minimal raises.
cons: Supervisors to the VP do not care about their employees at all. Long term highly experienced employees are leaving left and right. Set up system so they can see when you are in it. Unfair treatment of employees, at least 200 files no matter what level. No way to keep up, and management does not care. Supervisors, especially Australian get away with whatever they want. Supervisors promoted due to good ole boys, not because they know what they are doing. Dangerous place to work that has cause many employees physical ailments due to the relentless pressure and demands.

title: "Great culture, slow promotion"
pros: Great company to work for with a lot of really great people. Most are very friendly and personable. Good benefits and opportunities for development if you ask
cons: Hard to advance and can be very political. Pay not as good as some outside firms

title: "Overall great company with growth"
pros: Great company, progressive, comprehensive benefit package, including a full gym, discounts on local entertainment, and education opportunites and discounts. Advancement opportunities, but expect stringent internal competition.
cons: There is stringent internal competition for advancement so don't expect to move up quickly unless you are prepared to move locations frequently

title: "Okay place to work and learn"
pros: Inclusive environment for LGBT to work.
cons: Lacks African Americans in senior leadership positions in IT.

title: "Wonderfull company to work for"
pros: Leaders care about you and are your advocate
cons: Very large company in many states

title: "I have experience in performance review, service level analysis, continuous improvement, coaching and change management."
pros: I enjoy developing associates and coaching them into upper level positions. In addition, coaching associates to succeed in their current position.
cons: The opportunities to advance in your career are minimal in Lincoln, NE. In order to advance, you most be mobile.

title: "Growth & Development"
pros: Nationwide really provides many opportunities for growth and development. I started as an intern 15 years ago. I've been afforded the opportunity to work with different parts of our business, attend training sessions locally as well as at our corporate office.
cons: In my area there isn't really any cons from a development perspective. If you talk to your leader they will help you find opportunities to develop if you are performing in your current role.

title: "Best job experience"
pros: Great atmosphere, great managers, room for career growth and advancement, fun and relaxed environment.
cons: None that I can think of. I loved the job.

title: "Great laid back environment"
pros: Great people, great management! Great place to live for those who enjoys life in a small suburban towns. Salary is small comparing to big cities but very good comparing to such a small town. So it can be pros for some people and cons for others.
cons: Tasks are not very challenging(good) neither is salary. It's located in a small city of Columbus, not much to do here.

title: "Specialist, IT Applications"
pros: Great work life balance. Good pay and benefits. Great co-workers. Applications were designed well and great to learn on and understand.
cons: Many changes taking place. Management has been transparent about the changes and the impacts. It unknown how much or how many people will be impacted.

title: "Far more good than bad"
pros: -great work/life balance -awesome coworkers -leaders who want to see you succeed and support your goals/growth
cons: -parking for entry level associates is a major headache -opportunities to move up feel like they're more about timing, good fortune, and availability than performance -the pace might not be fast enough for some folks

title: "Analyst"
pros: Nice environment, clean, underground parking, decent benefits
cons: Extremely political, incompetent middle management, no growth opportunities

title: "Good place to work"
pros: Good salary, hours, environment. Company appreciates employee input, and encourages input - and then they actually act on the input. Up to date equipment and technology
cons: Very few cons. Biggest con is that any type of "promotion" requires interviewing, like interviewing for a new job. You don't go from an Associate I to Associate II without interviewing.

title: "Master Claims Rep"
pros: Fair wages, bene's, time off, a lot of good associates. Flexible work hours.
cons: Too much work, not enough help or empathy from upper management. Terrible work/home life balance.

title: "Fair Company to work for"
pros: Benefits, Co-workers, Vacation days, Good Management
cons: Parking, Push of health and people schedule meetings during classes

title: "Nice company to work for"
pros: Great people and work life balance. Company is also extremely supportive when it comes to continuing education.
cons: Pay in my particular area was a little lower than the industry average.

title: "Material Damage Auto Adjuster"
pros: Great Benefits (401K, Company Car, Medical/Dental), Allow you to do your job on your own schedule with limited impedemants
cons: Although they give you plenty of vacation time it can be tough to use it all, and especially when you want to. When others are out their is no real coverage and extra work can be too much at times

title: "IT Application intern"
pros: It was a great experience which involved lot of learning.The timing is flexible and the work culture is good. Agile work environment in real sense.
cons: Not Really any cons because the work atmosphere is really good and encouraging.

title: "Claims Specialist"
pros: Vacation time, coworkers and talking with customers and helping.
cons: The pay is horrible and not truly based on performance. Claims adjusters are not valued and have the hardest job.

title: "Great place!"
pros: Nationwide is a great place to work with ample opportunities for advancement.
cons: I don't have any cons.

pros: Great management that is very understanding to life issues.
cons: Its a temp job so you can only work a full year if you are full time.

title: "Great people! Lots of opportunities!"
pros: Great organization overall that supports its employees at every level and provides opportunities for professional growth and self development. Educational reimbursement is a huge plus!
cons: It's unfortunate that underwriting is being relocated and many employees cannot move with them. The relocation package isn't great, varies by pay band, and there isn't much incentive to move if salaries remain the same but cost of living is drastically higher at the new location. Plus, the workload keeps getting heavier and there are no signs of relief.

title: "Sales and Service Specialist"
pros: Nationwide really has the best customers.
cons: in the area i was in there was not much room for advancement unless you were willing to relocate

title: "Once you get into the corporate groove it's great."
pros: Decent culture for a big corporation. Great people to work with. Opportunity for advancement and training. There seems to be a genuine effort to keep employees happy. Earning potential is fair or (slightly) better. Much better product to offer than most other companies. All levels of management seem to be very approachable. Very nice mentoring program. Benefits are good except for ...
cons: ...health plan which is horrid. Metric chasing gets downright silly sometimes. Four different scheduling/calendar systems. Systems don't communicate wIth each other. Team structure provides an inconsistent experience. Limited candidate pool necessitates hiring questionable people. Micromanagement gets tiring. Middle management exhibits a Chicken Little reaction to normal business cycles in order to impress the next level up. There's a fairly narrow statistical window for trending analysis which feeds the chicken little mentality. IT department is very good but IT systems are not cutting edge.

title: "Business Consulting Analyst"
pros: Flexible work schedule, and decent benefits
cons: not as competitive salary and management doesn't give a clear view of future

title: "Positive"
pros: Good work like balance. Ok benefits.
cons: no potential for growth, not so fair compensation

title: "Financial Analyst"
pros: Pay, benefits and location downtown
cons: Work life balance and management team

title: "Claims Adjuster, Property Damage Subrogation"
pros: Great people to work with.
cons: No career path advancement opportunities directly from this position.

title: "Good place to work"
pros: Good place to work indeed
cons: Unfortunately there is a lot of subjectivity that influences managers decisions.

title: "material damage appraiser"
pros: The pay is decent and benefits are ok
cons: Unrealistic expectations in the volume of claims associates can handle and still do quality work

title: "Good Place to Work - Des Moines, IA - IT"
pros: - Good Culture that values people and personal accountability. - Company values a work/life balance - Consistently good people throughout my experience in multiple departments
cons: - Frequently office politics affects decisions in suboptimal ways - Leadership in IT is consolidating in Columbus, OH so there are limited opportunities

title: "Commercial Processor"
pros: It was very easy to move up within the company. Schedule was very flexible. Working on weekends was not required for my department.
cons: My department went through an attrition model and several employees were out of a job if they couldnt get hired within.

title: "Great company to work for"
pros: Many opportunities to advance and experience different business units.
cons: Might be difficult for some people to believe they can advance. Its very competitive environment where some associates build "kingdoms" to protect their roles.

title: "Great experience"
pros: Secure, respectful, generous, very diverse environment.
cons: very comfortable.. yes its a disadvantage sometimes.

title: "Difficult as a starting point in sales"
pros: Nice co-workers, auto and home insurance were good.
cons: Nationwide is one of the many names in insurance out there, so starting out in sales is very competitive and difficult, unless you have a large and receptive warm market. Pay is marginal for unestablished sales agents.

title: "Specialist, IT Applications Development"
pros: great environment and culture , nice activities, training
cons: lower rates that CHASE , average benefits , older technology

title: "Worth the Experience"
pros: Cool managers Get to shadow multiple teams Almost everyone is offered Full Time Can choose from type of work you want to do here
cons: Salary is on low side It depends upon a person to initiate. You could stay here without been getting noticed or complete your internship without doing anything.

title: "Great Customer Service - Poor Agent Service"
pros: Overall, great customer service and a great help desk for agents. I enjoyed my time working for the company and felt like I was truly able to help people understand the process of insurance.
cons: I attempted to apply to open an agency after working for Nationwide as an associate agent for over 4 years, but never heard a response back. Also, when I applied for appointment with Nationwide once I had my P&C and Life Insurance Licenses, it took them 7 months to verify and to get me appointed to sell with Nationwide.

title: "Sr. Analyst"
pros: Room to grow. Lots of people to learn from. People are nice.
cons: Management is slow to post requisitions that are badly needed. Raises and bonuses could be better.

title: "Intern experience"
pros: Good company with proper work life balance. Various opportunities to grow. I would recommend this company to job seekers in IT
cons: I really did not find any con while working here.

title: "Regional Internal Consultant"
pros: Great Place to work, Great Colleagues
cons: semi-political work environment can be frustrating

title: "Manager"
pros: Great Work/Life balance, caring leaders, friendly work environment.
cons: Expense reduction pressures on top of many transformational projects.

title: "Great work environment"
pros: There is a great focus on the associate and their needs which leads to a great working environment. The corporate structure is very positive.
cons: Too many leadership roles with no direct accountability for results

title: "Run fast!"
pros: Pay is decent. Can get away with just about anything...
cons: Promote based on who likes you. All political. Managers are clueless and paid to do nothing... Pile work on associates. Everyone is stressed.

title: "Claims Adjuster, Medical"
pros: The company itself loves their employees. They care to help you improve and move forward with your career.
cons: A lot of favoritism in certain teams.

title: "Sr. Admin Assist"
pros: Love the daily interaction with tenants and landlords. Position has a variety of responsibilities which make it very exciting.
cons: Some of the landlords can be very demanding and uncooperative at times.

title: "Great Company"
pros: Good Benefits, lots of training for employees. I still have them for my personal auto insurance
cons: numbers driven as any call center type position is.

title: "claim department"
pros: None with change over to Nationwide
cons: They demand so much data be input that you loose sight of the ultimate goal; to settle the claim. Original thinking, creative moves ae not noticed or appreciated, you are judged on the amount and quality of data you input.

title: "Columbus, Ohio"
pros: None I can think of
cons: A lot of change going on.

title: "Consultant, IT Analysis"
pros: Family atmosphere, work life balance
cons: Was a great place to work until the systems I work on got moved to Columbus and Harleysville. Des Moines will no longer exist as a Commercial IT shop...just some web apps and NWAG

title: "Marketing Intern"
pros: It had a great support system around the young people working there. Made me feel useful.
cons: Sometimes the size of the company makes you feel like you're just a cog in a machine, but that's what happens when you work at a large company.

title: "Legal Assistant"
pros: Great Benefits Generous time off Family Oriented
cons: Heavy Caseload, high turn over low morale

title: "Sales Manager"
pros: Excellent benefits, great opportunities, strong value statement, Leadership seems concerned with every stakeholder: Customers, employees, agents, vendors.
cons: Being a conservative company, we can move slow at times, but at least we are moving in the right direction. Since Nationwide owns several different insurance companies, they all have different operating platforms.

title: "Positive Environment"
pros: Friendly coworkers that are always super helpful and willing to teach new people. Managers are very friendly and seem to care about their workers. Nationwide is dedicated to helping you progress your career.
cons: High deductible health plan is awful. Workload for claims is very high.

title: "Run away as fast as you can!"
pros: The office space is nice. That is it!
cons: -No work life balance - High expectations and even higher workload -Workload is unbearable -Management caters to associates that they like -Management promotes associates that they like rather than those that are qualified -Lower pay than other insurance companies -Stress, stress, stress. -High turnover

title: "Great tone at the top"
pros: Culture is great, hours are great, lots of visibility from upper management, lots of opportunity for upward movement. well run company, great amenities.
cons: Nothing glaring. parking situation is pretty annoying, but if thats the one thing that primarily comes to mind then I think that says a lot.

title: "Strategy team"
pros: Great staff and good work. Very interesting with lot's of great people and a great company with strong engagement.
cons: Slower corporate culture and low turnover stifle growth opportunities. Also, strategy team struggles with execution due to corporation culture. i

title: "Solid Company"
pros: People are generally easy to work with and engaged. The company is very stable and does try to keep employee satisfaction high. Promotions are very possible for people with desire and that will work to improve their skill set. It is a generally very steady company and the senior leadership is visible and accessible.
cons: Like many companies the Red Tape is huge. Slow to change and when you are looking for advancement it can be a who you know vs what you know situation. Pay is low compared to the market. When managing employees it can be extremely difficult to terminate the person.

title: "mmcr2"
pros: pay was really super good.
cons: You could never get a day off.

title: "NW"
pros: Has both 401K and Retirement plan
cons: Salary as compared to the industry

title: "Insurance/mortgage"
pros: Vast experience in above listed fields with all insurance licenses intact. Great opportunity to expand my knowledge in the industries and specific areas in the field.
cons: The hours were not conducive to family life which reflected a lack of the core value of family/work balance needed with children.

title: "Over View"
pros: Flexible work schedule and a pleasant and relaxed work environment
cons: There are none that I see

title: "Financial Services Rep"
pros: great people and benefits, management and higher ups really care about your career development.
cons: Below average pay for position, other than that can't really think of much.

title: "Overview"
pros: Good work environment and co-workers
cons: I can't think of any at this moment

title: "Claims/Management"
pros: After 9 years, got pretty good pay and benes. Great co-worker relationships.
cons: They stress and grind out their claims people; year in and year out. They pushed out all their old people like me.

title: "Reputable and Fair"
pros: Very healthy balance between work and personal life. Nationwide as a whole was very helpful with training and establishing a new agency.
cons: Turnaround times need to be improved to ensure customers received the most accurate information in the least amount of time to avoid below average customer service efforts.

title: "Nationwide employee"
pros: Great company to work for benefit/pay wise
cons: Leadership doesn't always stick up and work for their employees

title: "Independent agents"
pros: Get to promote Nationwide products and help assist clients in making the right decisions for the insurance coverages. Strong company if you work for corporate not an independent agency
cons: Independent agency treat their agents with disrespect. I have a handicap issue and was harassed by the owner. I had no HR to turn to since the owner was the one discriminating against me.

title: "Admin Associate"
pros: i currently work at Nationwide Bank Mortgage, which is in a transitional period of change. The benefits packet for insurance/dental/vision is great.
cons: The transitional period is a little hard but eventually will all straighten out. Otherwise, there are not any other cons for me.

title: "Overall Company Review"
pros: They truly care about their employees
cons: Lots of Real Estate Change

title: "Associate Agent"
pros: Flexible hours, no salary cap, opportunity to grow into agency ownership. Good product and advertising subsidies. User-friendly software and lots of education opportunities.
cons: Continuously changing directives from company. Varying responsibility for costs of continuing education, E&O insurance, etc., depending upon primary agent. Focus on number rather than size and quality of sales.

title: "Insurance agent"
pros: Good pay, benefits, and flexability. Had fun, but the constant changes that are to improve the profits were annoying. Nor did they seem to work.
cons: Not consistent with bonuses. All agents in the office who do the same job should get similar bonuses. One year mine was higher than the other agents. The next year it was less. The owners just decide what to give and it's not fair. Of course we all will talk to each other.

title: "Sr. Recruiting Coordinator"
pros: Nationwide not only values their members, the also highly value their employees. I came from the public sector after 9 years and was worried about the work pace of the private sector. They not only support a work/life balance they also support the health and wellness of each employee. Fabulous place to work.
cons: I can't think of even one con about Nationwide. It's a new home away from home for me and there is no doubt in my mind that I will likely retire from this agency.

title: "retirement place"
pros: retirement place, over staffed company
cons: not good if expect growth

title: "PLSC Rep. III"
pros: Activities in regards to Associate Resource Groups and activities within the community that you can volunteer your time too.
cons: You end up having to "play the game" to get ahead which doesn't always work for everyone.

title: "Great Company"
pros: Good corporate citizen program. Care about employees. Highly engaged environment with like minded individuals. Most seem to enjoy weeking there
cons: Can get lost in the large environment.

title: "Positive"
pros: Nice company culture. Good place to work. They give time to settle as well.
cons: not that I could think of

title: "Sales Supervisor"
pros: Nationwide is a huge, Fortune 100 company with it's hands in almost everything that has to do with Insurance & Finance. They're a stable company that likes to promote from with in (provided the applicant is in Ohio).
cons: Nationwide is very Ohio minded since their headquarters and majority of work force is there. This is negative as it limits upward mobility for anybody working outside of Ohio. This can also be seen when exec's are chosen for subsidiary companies of Nationwide, they'll usually fill them with people from Ohio. Compensation is also Ohio minded. Having been an employee in California of a company they'd bought out, they're existing pay scale already considered me overpaid for their Ohio standards, not placing cost of living as a large concern. Nationwide is also very smart but frugal with the dollar. They're invested from the top on growing it into the largest insurance company in America, but the low pay and consistently higher goals are the prime path their taking to get there. All said, Great company to work for in Ohio. Anywhere outside, tough company to work for.

title: "Company Review"
pros: Good company to work with environment
cons: But very low salaries and not good

title: "New Associate"
pros: Care about growth of associate's career, Great work environment, Managers engage with associates monthly to discuss feedback and career goals.
cons: Salary may be less but benefits make up for less salary. Business organizations are treated to team outings and group engagement activities while others have less

title: "IT Development"
pros: Great people, Great company. I have been working here for more than 10 years
cons: really do not anything to say

title: "CL Processor"
pros: The employees live out their company values and really care about you as a person. The management does a good job pushing your development, but not in an overbearing way.
cons: As with many of the other big companies, there are a lot of changes with the industry. Management seems to want their hand and shift toward micromanaging a bit more.

title: "Independent Insurance Agent"
pros: Good competitive products with opportunity for growth.
cons: No salary incentive at start up. All commission if you're applying with no base or book of business.

title: "Associate Underwriter"
pros: Nationwide provides quality training. Prior to rolling out any changes the appropriate training is provided to make sure it is seamless to the customers.
cons: Very fast past. Production oriented atmosphere. Very difficult to develop a workplace home life due to the volume of policy renewals.

title: "Great Place to Work"
pros: Benefits Close to zero micromanagement Great people and great place to learn the business Nationwide promotes its employees to different roles, the average associate with 10 years with the company had 3-4 different roles
cons: Company is centralizing roles and it may be a little more competitive.

title: "Member Care Representative"
pros: Welcoming and caring culture. Good pay and good benefits. Clean and modern atmosphere. Great company values towards members and employees.
cons: The systems are tedious to use and navigate. Can be stressful for an entry level position.

title: "Financial Representative"
pros: Nationwide really invests in its employees and has amazing benefits
cons: Salary is nothing to brag about

title: "On Your Side"
pros: Nationwide does an excellent job in branding their products - kudos to the Marketing Team. The corporate culture is light years ahead of the "good ol' boys club" that comprises upper management for most other captive carriers. The training is excellent on the corporate level.
cons: The computer systems could be better integrated and a district marketing budget would go far in establishing a community presence. As it is, each Agent is on their own and most cannot afford to pump unlimited funds into marketing.

title: "Software Quality Assurance"
pros: Very nice place to work.
cons: No cons to add at the moment.

title: "Decent Job"
pros: Flexible company with growth ability and great name recognition. The company believes in giving customers numerous ways to add discounts to policies.
cons: Lack of loyalty from customers made it very hard for retention. Also, the pay as an associate agent isn't that great, lots of improvement there.

title: "Independent Contractor Agent"
pros: Great company culture Unlimited earning opportunity Great claims service
cons: Strategic direction constantly changing More on line and direct competition

title: "Sr. Admin. Secretary"
pros: Great work environment. At the Virginia Operations center you are motivated to work not pressured! It a great place to work.
cons: There are no cons. I moved out of state and wish I had a Nationwide office close enough to go back too. I am hoping to find another company that treats it's employees this well.

title: "Need Training About Products and Selling"
pros: Nationwide is a company that has integrity and makes it clear that our members are the priority. The underwriters, adjusters, and customer service professionals are always available to us and have been trained to reach resolution on issues with one contact if possible. They have answered many questions for me as I work directly with our members.
cons: At my agency, the primary agent has provided mostly OJT which is not adequate. I have been able to go to a couple of two day classes, but most of what was taught was how to negotiate the software. I pushed really hard to go to life insurance training, but have to buy my own plane ticket to Ohio. Truthfully, I am looking for another position at another company that guarantees better training so that I can do what I am capable of.

title: "Program Agent"
pros: Nationwide had a great product line up and great program to get you started. The also having great training for newer agents.
cons: Poor pay on life sales and low commissions when compared to other companies. Managers move around to much when working with new agents.

title: "Desperate Company"
pros: Treated employees well but that's about it
cons: Spiraling out of control. No sense of direction. Company has no direction for the future and it will soon cost them substantially.

title: "If you are thinking about accepting an offer, think again!"
pros: The pay is competitive, you can make a decent salary if you negotiate well in the beginning. Being an adjuster gives you lots of freedom because you set your own schedule, as long as you are organized and get your work done you are golden. If you come prepared with some knowledge, they are willing to train you. Company car with perks.
cons: Overwhelming workload, consistently short staffed, no work/home life balance, highly stressful and demanding. Managers don't manage, they supervise. Nationwide seems to be the grandfather of the insurance world, they are apprehensive about change, and once they are forced to change to adapt to technology, etc. they overhaul everything rapidly, at once and expect nothing less than perfection during the transition. Not very diverse when it comes to gender or race. They don't have their employees best interests at hand. It's nearly impossible to be spontaneous with vacation time and if you leave the company before 5 years, they don't cash out your vacation time or allow you to take it--they absorb it back into the company as if you did not earn it. They are very mechanical and stiff with it comes to their employees interests. It's hard to move around within the company unless you are willing to relocate.

title: "Unit Manager"
pros: Good work life balance, career progression
cons: Outdated technology and management philosophies

title: "AM Revie"
pros: Great brand, great claims department
cons: Strict Underwriting, Lack of Agency structure and management

title: "Underwriter"
pros: Very few, 401k is good, nice co workers for the most part.
cons: Extremely top heavy. Arrogant leadership who can't see the forrest through the trees. Deceptive and dishonest leaders throughout the organization. Good ole boy network. Lack of respect for front line employees. Pay is lower than competitors.

title: "Customer service Rep"
pros: Great pay, good company to work for
cons: Went through 2 company consolidations/layoffs due to downsizing

title: "Great place to work!"
pros: - work / life balance is fantastic - opportunities for career development - associate engagement is always high - salary and benefits - culture and people are great to work with
cons: - largeness of company allows for some individuals to get by without doing much work - parking can be difficult downtown

title: "Manager"
pros: Large company, decent benefits, reputable company
cons: Pay is less than competitors, good ole boys network in some locations, field locations treated like "step children", not much room for advancement; VERY political atmosphere. Can't be honest and truthful-that has negative results on your career advancement.

title: "Salary"
pros: Great company with awesome moral. The pay is low to industry standard for an internal wholesaler but also don't have the stress as you do with other companies
cons: Glass ceiling when it comes to pay

title: "Phone Screener"
pros: good experience if you want to be a telemarketer and not learn a thing while working
cons: everything about the job. lowest man on the totum pole and they don't let you forget it

title: "Sales"
pros: Products & great company in general
cons: Salary & no benefits

title: "Receptionist"
pros: Good enough while I was there
cons: I cant really say or this review wont be submitted like last time

title: "Good place to work"
pros: They have freat benefits and great people
cons: Paying for parking and being on a waitlist of 2000 people to get a parking spot

title: "Amazing company"
pros: Good pay , holidays ,overtime pay
cons: Insurance premiums but that's everywhere . Parking sucks unless you get a near by garage .

title: "if workload was less would be 5 stars. very stressful. no work life balance for field adjusters."
pros: management seems to care about employees. growth potential. different areas of business to make lateral moves. pay is above average.
cons: not enough time to accomplish tasks. late hours. not a lot of empowerment to make decisions on the fly. too much emphasis on customer service not technical skills

title: "Great Culture"
pros: Very nurturing and caring management staff
cons: None to speak of at this time

title: "Underwriter"
pros: Great place to work with great benefits
cons: Antiquated systems and lack of technology

title: "Director"
pros: Worked with some very trustworthy and ethical people. Really enjoyed the associates and many of the people I worked with over the years.
cons: At the management level, not much praise or training. Associates receive some great training, but managers and up learn as they go. Not very open in hiring practices and the compensation for the amount and quality of work expected is lower than the industry.

title: "Financial Advisor"
pros: Access to a warm market
cons: Lots of strings attached. Business gets taken away from you from other agents. Not want they paint out position to be.

title: "mixed bag"
pros: good benefits, some good people do work there, if mgmt believed in the values, it has potential.
cons: way too much favoritism, but, if you can get mgmt to like you, you are golden. relocating is just a fancy term for down sizing. One cannot make an uw decision without sales involved. Pay is below average for this size carrier. You should try to help those employees who are losing their jobs to find new positions within the company.

title: "Administrative Assistant"
pros: Nice location. Solid company with great benefits. Promotes diversification, fairness, and respect. Covered parking. Flex hours. Work at home (in certain positions) is offered.
cons: Cubical walls are not high enough. You can hear everyone near you, which can be very distracting all day long.

title: "Property Casualty Processor"
pros: Company is very community-oriented allowing employees to volunteer their time to different organizations.
cons: Difficult to move thru the company Some of the job positions are contract employees. Need to pay-attention to news letters if company does a reorganization or realignment of job positions. My position was moved to Cleveland.

title: "Loan Counselor"
pros: great benefits, provides free parking ramp in a busy downtown area.
cons: not the easiest to transfer departments

title: "Nationwide"
pros: Free Parking, Fitness Center, Some benefits are good
cons: Low compensation, hard to move to different areas

title: "Great place to work"
pros: Nationwide has generous time off policies, a good pay scale, and generally a great environment to work in.
cons: Experience of work definitely depends on management. Some managers are just not good and that affects everything.

title: "Senior Consultant, Process Management"
pros: Work life balance. Lots of training opportunities. People are nice.
cons: Lots of people seem to have very little to do. Not very highly skilled people. Little consistency in strategy - as leadership changes, so does philosophy and direction. Near constant org changes.

title: "Nice perks"
pros: There is a gym in office. There are also cafeterias and nearby food within walking distance. They also provide free parking for employees.
cons: There are lots of new employees constantly being hired. Training is a very long process, probably about three months of time.

title: "Call Center"
pros: Pay is average for a position such as this, but maybe not for the amount of responsibilities required of a senior supervisor
cons: One in the call center it is so disconnected from the rest of the company it is hard to transfer

title: "Customer Service Representative"
pros: -Coworkers -Benefits -Salary -Great training program -Really great company, good future -Advancement opportunities
cons: -Call center work is not for everyone. -Days off are split through the week -Some customers call in very angry

title: "Nationwide Insurance"
pros: great people in Denver office, company supports the community
cons: so much change, leadership moving and things not settled.

title: "Insurance Sales Agent for Nationwide"
pros: Great environment and management is very relaxed.
cons: Workload is heavy from being understaffed.

title: "Retired"
pros: Being a employee for 35 years one learn professionalism and excellent customer service,
cons: There could be more career advancement

title: "Attorney"
pros: Nice salary and retirement.
cons: Health Benefits are awful, deductible is too high.

title: "Sr Analyst"
pros: Great Company. Competitive pay, great benefits, great environment
cons: Standard corporate America problems that you'd expect of any Fortune 100 organization.

title: "Operations"
pros: Nice benefits, accrued time off from the firs week. A lot of Good people there. On sight cafeteria, covered parking.
cons: Work load was Insane. Production standards outdated! Felt like working in a Sweat Shop! Bad training. Management would not listen to any requests. Need new management and treat people like people not machines!

title: "Member Care Rep"
pros: Decent pay, shift differential for later shifts, 18 days of pto, easy to advance.
cons: There seems to be a lack of transparency at times with upper level management. It's difficult to schedule time off in this dept.

title: "Claims Specialist I"
pros: Had an awesome team manager
cons: Office politics were very heavy

title: "Member Care Rep"
pros: Great Environment Great Culture Great Pay and Benefits The Pro's out weight the cons
cons: Career Growth is Limited unless you are mobile

title: "Medical Claims Specialist II"
pros: -Great work environment -Customers are a pleasure to work with (Internal & External)
cons: -Lack of growth within the area/region (Southeast) -Pay scale is lower then other insurance companies in the region

title: "Internal Wholesaler"

cons: Higher salary (40-50k) with limited upside on incentives & commissions (10-15k). Micromanaged to death on performance metrics and no autonomy to manage your assigned territory. Limited career advancement opportunities within sales other than a outside sales rep.

title: "Excellent Work Culture!"
pros: - Great overall learning experience - Work - life balance - Room for growth and development
cons: - Need to have more geographical flexibility

title: "Employee"
pros: Great company with a good vision for the future
cons: Closing all of their Lincoln NE locations

title: "Company Review"
pros: The benefits, pay and flexible schedules were what kept me there for several years.
cons: The culture is highly competitive, bullying and inappropriate behavior are pervasive throughout the company.

title: "Its OK"
pros: good work/life balance, people try to do the right thing
cons: frequent re-orgs and direction changes

title: "Not for everyone"
pros: -Decent benefits -Great Paid Time Off
cons: -Office Politics -Micro mgmt -Constant changes -Call center is almost slave labor -Constant weekly, monthly and yearly reviews on performance made it a drag

title: "Project Staff"
pros: Nationwide is a great company to work for. They care about people and do a great job enabling good work life balance. It's also a great place to expand your career without leaving the company.
cons: Hard to get promoted after a certain level and they keep flattening the organization.

title: "lots of work"
pros: nice co workers, great management
cons: not enough money for what they expect of you

title: "Business Consultant"
pros: Good place to work and grow
cons: Not enough flexibility for work life balance

title: "Liability Adjuster"
pros: - Easy interview process/Always hiring - PTO starting is 18 days with options to donate blood and get more PTO - Young crowd in non-injury claims, cool coworkers
cons: - LOW starting pay for industry standards and they say that in your 6-8 months you get a huge 20% raise, but that's not s guarantee--- And they expect you to work nights and weekends or any open shift that they need you to work - Claim work load can be very overwhelming and unmanageable and management doesn't seem like they care to even out the claim load between shifts - VERY "mid west" company with no innovation for the future- Management is stuck in the "old" way of business like having a strict dresscode (when the job is 90% on the phone... who cares if I'm in jeans, I can do my job just fine) - Office politics.. Depending on your manager, it can feel very micromanaged- If you finish your work 10 minutes early and want to leave, depending on the manager you could "get in trouble" - Time commitment to the department you are hired in is 18 months, which can feel like forever and when the 18 months is up there are about 20 people all trying to get promoted to the same open position - Unfair "grading" system- some managers give promotions and bonuses to those who they like that do not preform well at all... It matters more that management likes you, not the quality of the work you do - At the end of the day, it's claims- you're talking to upset/impatient people who expect you to bend over backwards for them and they still yell at you for not doing enough. No one understands their policy coverages and a lot of the time you're "wrong" when you had nothing to do with the issue at hand. It's a very thankless job.

title: "Claims Robot"
pros: Decent salary, good benefits, lazy managers means you can be lazy too
cons: Dealing with angry/upset/ridiculous people on the phone, overwhelming claim volume at times, unfulfilling work

title: "Account manager"
pros: Friendly people, great work environment, family friendly, potential for advancement
cons: Bureaucratic, resistant to change in some areas

title: "Good organization to work for"
